It almost put me off of my hunger, but I pushed through because we knew of no other place to go. 

The omelet I was served was about the worst omelet I'd ever had. It was overcooked, dry, and flavorless. Y'know, it's pretty hard to mess-up an omelet. The home-fries were also bland, soft, and mushy. What is it with places that don't make crispy home-fries?! Does anybody actually ~like~ non-crispy home fries?!

The only reason I'm not giving this place one star is that our server (an older gay gentleman) was kind of a hoot. He was sassy and sarcastic and at least kept us amused and well-stocked on coffee while we choked-down our unappetizing breakfast.
author: Robert F.

description:
An open letter to Orphan Andy's:

Listen bitch,
you're wearing a skirt, he's wearing foundation & he's got on junior jeans I used to wear in 6th grade. 
When you do your damndest to incorporate feminine details, don't ignore the source when women come into this establishment.

I can't tell you how many times I've been ignored when I've come with just girls vs. given attentive service when I've come in with both boys & girls.
author: Em L.

description: So very disappointed at my last visit here. I will say when coming to Orphan Andy's in the past I was greeted sweetly, seated immediately,(if there was space available) and had my order taken within 5 mins to getting seated. My questions this time around...What went wrong?! Did customer service go down the drain that bad since my last visit?!  Me and my sister came in on a not so busy day and stood around to get seated. No one even noticed us. 10 minutes passed and we then proceeded to seat ourselves. We sat at the booth another 10 mins and still no acknowledgement. We were beyond annoyed. I finally went to the cash register to see what the big hold up was. The only cashier on shift at the time was on the phone! (Really!?) I interrupted his phone call and asked polity for a couple of Menus.  Thats when the Cashier rudely shoved the menus in front of me and said it would be another 5 mins. The nerve of that man!  I went back to my sister with the menus and she was already picking up her purse saying, "It's time to go." and with that we left. We literally spent 25 mins there, just to get ignored. My sister said she's never going there again but as for me, it's going to take some time Orphan Andy's but I may be back...
author: Meg J.

description: This place is fucking amazing!! There food quality is so bomb. If you're looking for a homemade meal, and I'm talking legit homemade, this is the spot to be at. Even if you're drunk and hungover. 10+ stars
author: Fabian B.

description: Absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE this place , it's always great service whenever I come here ! The guys are always so happy & do whatever it takes to make sure you have a great experience at orphan Andys !!  I'm sold . I rave about this place all the time whenever a breakfast debate breaks out !! The French toast is to die for I get the same every single time I come here !!! Thank you for always making my tummy so happy
author: Princess E.

description:
Looking for a place to get some food after  a long night out?? --- This place is perfect. 

Its got a great eclectic crowd, (I've only been there late nights) - so you walk in and sometimes there is a line. Drag queens, club goers, people coming off swing shifts... 

The menu isn't bad and it is everything you want out of a greasy spoon diner. *Love*

One thing though, beware of the bathroom. It took some extreme acrobatics in there to not touch anything -- shit smears on the toilet seat and all. Gross.
author: Kate D.

description:
24-hr food spots in the city are a rarity, so thank goodness for Orphan Andy's. I've been here twice -- once to grab a late night snack with my boyfriend and another time after a night out with friends in the Castro. Good homestyle cooking -- can get a little greasy, but if it's 330am, everything else is closed, and being picky isn't really an option, this is your place. The seating can get pretty tight, so I'd say come here with groups of 2-4 people. You can either sit at the counter or wait to be seated at a booth.

It's located right off of Market at the gateway to Castro. You can't miss it.
author: Camille B.

description:
Ugh! Why do I come to this place. I'm always expecting the burger to be better than the last. I want to like this place but I can't. The burger this time was a bit chewy (eww). There wasnt anything else open for a burger so I opted for this place. There's always someone drunk inside, some twink who drank too much and from the looks of it, ready to puke. 

NOTE TO SELF: stop coming here stupid!
author: V R C.

description: Ya know, I love Orphan Andy's, the service is always really good, the food is always hot and they have above average portions. I live for the Splendid Fare omelette in the morning, and a pastrami sandwich for lunch. The new coconut and pineapple cake is simply life changing. I appreciate places like Andy's when I want to feel like I'm eating someplace "real". Cooked to order is here to stay!
author: Erik M.

description: Love that this place is 24 hours and the eclectic crowd of people that gather here to eat. This place is especially interesting after 1 a.m. The food, not as exciting...
author: Melissa M.

description:
Just smile for that extra star please!..
Seriously super nice place, great food , great people. But certain employee just has that frown on his face all the time that makes me have to write about him.
author: Kato R.

description: the best neighborhood diner for the best neighborhood! open 24 hours. open minded staff. solid diner food. everyone friendly, from kids to the the silent, stalwart regulars of indeterminable age. may it live long!
author: Hm S.

description: Kindest, most upbeat service we'd had in the last 2 weeks of eating out everyday (due to being in a hotel b/c our apt. flooded)! Food was good and the music was awesome :)
author: Hayley T.

description: Well....for starters they forgot my order....and then when they finally took it, I got food poisoning. Like, why even bother. Wtf
author: A. B.

description:
Keeping this short.

Typical diner, friendly people working = Can't go wrong!

My friends and I were kind of buzzed going here and have had no type of substance in our stomachs, so I just ordered the philly cheesteak. It was pretty good.

I'm sure I'll return whenever I'm back in the area for some late night grub or a quick meal with friends.
author: Kim T.

description:
The chili here is DELISH! (Normally, I stay away from ordering chili at restaurants, but something made me order it one day). 

And the pancakes...Oh! The pancakes!

The atmosphere is fun-diner-style, and the staff are always friendly.
author: Jenna H.

description: I love Orphan Andys- The burgers are just incredible! I took my parents last time- we are all Scottish and the waiter we had was so kind to us. He told us stories about his trips to Scotland and made us all feel really special. He even gave us a taste of ice cream and seemed really passionate about the food and how it was made (5 ingredients in these hotcakes!! FIVE!). Just an outstanding place to go eat, my parents won't forget the service and the food
author: Bla B.

description:
I'm going to start my review by saying this place has the most amazing butter I have ever tasted. It's creamy, kept at the perfect temperature, and compliments every breakfast item it's slathered in. 
I came in on a Saturday morning and it was a bit of a wait to get though the door, maybe 15-20 minutes. But the wait was worth it. The place is small and cozy, super inviting. 
The waiter provided great service. He was super friendly checked up on us very frequently. 
The menu has typical diner items, breakfast options include omelettes, pancakes, French toast, etc. 
I went for the spinach feta omelette and side of potatoes. They use three eggs for their omelettes so that already makes them huge and then they stuff them with so much fresh spinach and cheese. You are getting your money's worth here. 
I also had a bite of my boyfriend's pancakes. They were delicious! 
Simple ingredients, simples recipes, but with an old fashioned twist that is hard to replicate at your own home. Open 24 hrs too! So be sure to stop by.
author: Lissette V.

description:
Greasy diners are as American as lotto tickets and toilet paper cozies. They must exist in order for the culinary elitists to snub and throttle with vitriolic abandon. And what would the Castro be like without its Orphan Andy, Li'l Annie's butch brother with the scrub-brush mustache and Popeye forearms? Because surely, the sun'll come out tomorrow...bet your bottom dollar that tomorrow there'll be sun...

My friend and I were lucky enough to grab the round table in front of the window this morning as it is often amusing to watch the nattily-appointed and sometimes not-so-well-attired passers-by turning from Market onto Castro. Both of us went immediately for the Hearty Fare section of the menu after giving the obligatory glance at the Diet Plates. I got the Sausage Links & Eggs (sunny side up please) with a hefty side of home fries and sourdough toast. My friend got the Scrambled Eggs with Diced Ham with two good-sized hotcakes. Both dishes were $7.75.

We were able to share, and I have to say that the pancakes were quite tasty this morning whether that is an anomaly or not. I know It's Tops gets the glory, but Andy's does give them a run for their batter. And the ham in the scrambled eggs were actually julienned, so there was a hefty amount of protein in them eggs. And my chicken apple sausage was just a tad greasy, though the potatoes were particularly absorbent. And I have a tendency to douse everything in Tabasco, so I didn't even notice.

Service is terrific, as the staff are long-timers. I try not to stare at the big toothpick pierced through his nose, but I just can't help myself. And he came by a lot to fill up my coffee cup. I know it ain't the greatest place nor the healthiest, not by a foodie mile...but if you don't have to wait, if you just want a big breakfast on a chilly morning, then Andy's does work. It also works really late at night when the female impersonators come in, a show in itself!

FOOD - 4 stars...hits the spot for me when I need a greasy spoonful
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a tiny place in need of a paint job but a convenient location nonetheless
SERVICE - 4 stars...fast and friendly and oh-so-fabulous
TOTAL - 4 stars......tomorrow...tomorrow...I'll love ya tomorrow...tomorrow's just a day away!
author: Ed U.

description:
Orphan Andy's is a cute diner situated in the prime of the Castro. Tonight was my first time visiting and my expectations were met. I don't necessarily like when my expectations are met, especially for a restaurant in San Francisco. 

For my meal I ordered the super chicken sandwich, and it was essentially chicken fingers, cole slaw, lettuce, one tomato slice, mayo, and two pickle chips sandwiched between two excessively large pieces of bread. I understand this is only a diner, but San Francisco is home to so many restaurants that it becomes essential to add something else to stick out from the rest. The meal was hot but my french fries were over cooked (VERY crispy and crunchy, I don't like that). My friend ordered the reuben which he seemed to enjoy.

As for service, our waiter was very nice but he seemed aggravated/pissed off when I only wanted to drink water. He even came back and asked me if I changed my mind and wanted to order another beverage. Why can't I just have water? My friend got coffee and they never let him see the bottom of his cup, that was quite nice. It took a while for us to get our food (despite the fact the restaurant was pretty empty) but what I like about Orphan Andy's is that you can scope out the inhabitants of the Castro while waiting for your food. There was one server (blonde hair) who thought he was smoking hot or something, like settle down, you're not. 

Overall, when I went to pay our meal it came to $21 which was less than what I expected. The food was cheap, greasy, but I was definitely full afterwards. It's cool how they're open 24 hours but unless I'm drunk in the Castro at 3am, I don't know if I'll come back. San Francisco just has way too many great options to choose from; why settle for average?
author: Tommy C.

description:
Just had a late night meal with my gal pal's Bex and Lori and glad we did.
Been coming here for decades but it's a place I don't eat at alot. After tonight's meal, I might be coming here more often. 

Our friendly, smiling and ever so helpful waiter "Alex" gave us his honest opinions about our breakfast for dinner choices, he also makes a mean shake and malt.

I ordered one of the specials, pancakes and fried chicken. Lets just say I hoped for the best but planned for the worst. The pancakes were the best I have had in a long time. Two very large and fluffy plate sized pancakes that were hot with a generous serving of butter. The fried chicken was piping hot, crispy crust but moist and cooked through inside, 3 pieces plus a wing so 3.5 really. 

This meal was so good it would have made Julia Childs and Jenny Craig cry!
author: David P.

description:
The highlight of sitting at Orphan Andy's on a late night is the people watching...and it's not the people coming in you're looking at, but rather the interesting mix of people walking right on by.  (The waiter had a great laugh when he pointed out the drunk girl who tripped out in the middle of the street.  Now, that's entertainment!)

Who walked in after midnight and the place was pretty full for a Tuesday.  The few tables that were empty had yet to be cleared, and the waiter warned us he was short-staffed tonight.  We got one of those coveted window tables and ordered a hot chocolate each and a brownie a la mode to share.

The hot chocolate still had the powder mix that had yet to be stirred and the whipped cream was absent.  After perusing their limited dessert menu and finding out mostly everything was sold out, we finally settled on the brownie.  It's good enough for two and we didn't finish it all.    

Yes, the waiters are a chatty bunch and friendly enough (it helps when they smell nice too).

Sad to say, this was my first visit to Orphan Andy's after living in the city practically all my life.  Perhaps I'll check out the rest of their menu the next time I visit.  

Side note: My friend had to pee, but she absolutely refused to use their restroom saying her past experiences there were horrifying.  (It was her idea to eat there in the first place!) We had to leave because her bladder was about to bust!  (Can someone else vouch for their restrooms?)
author: Teri C.

description:
Come here for your standard late-night cheap diner food, and either be intoxicated or have no expectations of good food.  Orphan Andy's simply offers average diner food at average diner fare.  I was, however, very disappointed by the ice cream -- it was soft and melt-y, too fluffy and not smooth and creamy, and overall worse than Breyer's, Edy's, or even Safeway brand ice cream!  If you are craving ice cream do yourself a favor and order it in milkshake form.

On another note though, I'm not sure why so many Yelpers have complained about the service - our server was very nice!!
author: Beatrice W.

description: Waiting for 10 mins for the server to come in, ordered a soup with a an entree waiting for 15 mins the ready made soup is not serve, we cancelled the soup coz I think they r planning to serve it after our meal
author: Wendell P.

description:
I went here looking for some good hang-over brunch food. 

Got a full plate of potatoes, toast, and eggs (veggie omelette) with a coffee. My food experience was neither outstanding or disappointing. Just your average diner food. 

However, I sat at the bar and thought the waiters were a riot...I loved how nice/genuine they were. That can make all the difference!

Felt very comfortable....like I was at home...and would come again.
author: Emily Y.

description:
As a quirky sort of a joke, coupled with an homage to our first date (at a diner), the boyfriend and I spent our six month-iversary at Orphan Andy's.

I had very little expectations of the place (VERY little). I mean, c'mon, it's a diner. And as I've complained before (see: Bob & Edith's Diner review, http://www.yelp.com/biz/bob-and-ediths-diner-arlington-2#hrid:aagAHjbXicIZ3_d57WaRwA), diners aren't a place to hold high expectations--or any expectations for that matter. Your food may be cold and it may be greasy, but you should know that going into an eatery that specializes in fried food and won't cost you and your date half a months' paycheck.

With that being said, I liked this place. The service was friendly and the patrons were polite (it was a Monday evening--not too many drunkards...yet). 

Favorites:
+Orange juice: pulpy and fresh-squeezed
+Eggs: cooked exactly the way I wanted
+Pancakes: fluffy with a hint of cinnamon
+French toast: Not too egg-y; you know what I'm talking about. And yes, that's a good thing.

Not so favorites:
--Breakfast sausage: Pretty sure I bit into the pig's snout portion. Not yummy.
--Butter served with hotcakes/French toast: I don't need four ounces of the stuff, guys. Really.

I don't plan on rushing back here anytime soon, but if I'm ever in the mood for greasy breakfast during late-night hours, I won't hesitate to revisit this joint.
author: Adena B.

description: Best 24hr place in san framcisco hands down. I find myself constantly surprised at the quality of the food. I hate tuna melts but I eat the hell out of theirs. I only wish there was more seating.
author: Jacklyn H.

description:
I think you get get everything you'd expect here out of a diner in the Castro. Lots of greasy American fare and a lot more sass. I enjoyed the food and the chocolate shake (though for $6, I was admittedly expecting at least a pound of ice cream), but honestly server went above and beyond in being a jerk. I get it. It's his schtick. But I was hungover and didn't need to be told it was my fault that he forgot my milkshake. 

I'm sure others will gripe that that's half the fun of Orphan Andy's, but if he were actually good at his job, and not just being an ass, then he'd be able to tell when customers weren't amused and tone it down some. He acted like we should feel privileged to over-pay for mediocre grease-laden Americana.

Maybe it's much more interesting trashed at 2am?
author: Chris S.

description: I've come here for years and never had a problem but  now the new staff is less than desirable. Again, I always loved this placed, it's sad to see it go downhill.
author: Lynette E.

description: Cute, tiny, welcoming neighborhood spot with great diner food and wonderful servers. Would definitely go back!
author: Kristin L.

description:
I love Orphan Andy's because:
- You get to choose where to sit
- The staff that I've met thus far are all friendly and personable
- They are open 24hrs

I have tried their Steak Sandwich with Fries which was pretty tasty. I asked for it to be cooked medium and it came out well-done. It wasn't too big of a deal because it is a diner; now if I were at a steakhouse I would have returned it. The sandwich itself could have been more delectable if it was paired with a sauce of some sort. 

I have also tried their Country Fried Steak with scrambled eggs and pancakes. The winner was definitely the pancakes. They were the fluffiest pancakes I have ever eaten! 

I will certainly be back!

TIPS:
- The restroom is located downstairs past the kitchen on the right; it's a bit awkward walking through the kitchen but the cooks that I've come across have all been friendly
- Parking can be tough, I would recommend parking on Collingwood and walking from there
author: Juliette R.

description:
Ever wanted to dine beneath a framed print of naked Freddy Mercury doing unspeakable things to a dolphin's blowhole? This is your place!

Actually, it's good food, kind people, and a warm, homey diner feeling. It's got San Francisco pricing, but that's my only complaint. I love this li'l diner. Wish I could eat there more often.

But yeah. That Freddy Mercury print. Weird.
author: Christine S.

description: Oh Orphan Andy's...why must you be so rude.  No one was there, but some how we had to wait 5-10mins to get a menu.  Then another 15mins and no one came to take our order after we asked 3 times (maybe that was our mistake?).  We had to get up and leave because it didn't look like it was going anywhere :(
author: Jaime L.

description:
You know, I've been coming here pretty routinely for 3 years. Every month (or more) after a doctors appointment I'd come here for a late lunch / early dinner. The service and attitude was pretty friendly and outgoing which is something that's pretty important to me. Over the past year though, the service AND food has really gone down hill. They hired a new cook and when ever he's at the stove, I get sick. The waitstaff has really gone down hill, too! Really wish Richard wasn't on the morning shift or else I'd come in for something safe like french fries. 

I was in there yesterday after a routine doctors appointment. As always, I grabbed a menu and sat down in my usual spot - corner table in the front so that all the tourists can stand there and take secret pictures when they think you're not looking. The waiter - a tall, short dark hair - guy walked over and asked, "anymore in your group?" and I said no. Great, I should have said there were 20 in my group because it just went down hill from there - it was instant attitude. He made a point of setting my silverware (when he came back) across the table - as if I might squirt estrogen on him so, he better stay as far away as possilbe. He took my order which, I very politely gave him - 1 overpriced Ceasar Salad ($7.45 for lettuce, a glob of cheap Parmesan cheese in the middle and a couple of croutons with a drenching of Ceasar Dressing), a side of bacon and a Red Bull. I got a glass or water which, I had not ordered (apparently they don't watch the news - only serve water when requested). Still, no Hi! or How are you? You could feel the attitude as he made a point of no eye contact or speech. If you're having a bad, then check it at the door and paint on your happy face! 

I got my overly wilted salad and ate what I could because my mouth was starting to burn from the over abundance of Ceasar Dressing, drank my Red Bull and ate my bacon. My meal was served with my check (never had that happen before nor, did I see anyone else eating with a check on their table). WTF is wrong with you people? What happened to this place? Why all the attitude, especially to faithful and heavy tippers (I personally tip based on service, not percentage - people have walked away with a tip equaling the bill or more before). I got up, paid my bill - I really didn't want to leave a tip but, left a $2 tip on a $14 check which, I felt was more than fair. As I walked out the door I got a very catty "Byyyye" which, I have heard on many occasion from Chad and then proceed to piss and moan about their tip. 

Want better tips people? Work on the attitude. Want better customers? Work on the quality of food - you all are slipping and making your customers sick, or are the sick customers selective? I said to myself when I made it out the door - I'm done with this place, I don't pay for attitude and discomfort. Sorry folks, there are better places in the area with better service and cuisine that matches the price.
author: Jamilah A.

description: i must say after a night of dancing, drinking cranberry vodkas with friends at a bar nearby, the chicken fried steak breakfast hit the spot. Cooked to perfection, and the right spices. The staff here were amazing! Definately coming back again and suggesting to friends looking for a place to go to for breakfast.
author: Kay S.

description: So rude. Jesus. I'm so hungry and Orphan Andy's is rigt next to my buss stop. I went to eat there first time to try something new. The waiter wasn't there. So I sat alone at a booth. This dude rushes in and walks up to me and asks how many to your party. I say one. And he gives a huge sigh and points to a sign that says 2 minimum for a booth. I said uhhh I can move..? He says Hella loud NO it's fine. Got up and told him don't worry about it and walked out. He called after me aww c'mon. But I told him he was rude and left. Not giving this diner a dime.
author: Justin A.

description:
This place is the cutest! 

We visited with a local and felt right at home. I had a hot sausage sandwich, others had meatloaf, biscuits and gravy, and chilli. 

The waiter was super friendly and helpful. 

Only downside: portions were too big!
author: Jonathan W.

description: The service is really good, but the food is not. I've been going there five times and it's getting worse every time. I could taste the unclean kitchen in my food as well as smell it in the kichen, when I went through the kitchen to the restroom. Makes me sick to think what I just ate.
author: Ats N.

description:
Your options for above average-dining are few and far between in The Castro and Orphan Andy's is no exception. I've been here multiple times in many scenarios. Whether  I'm here drunk passed out in a plate of french fries or sober on a friend's whim, my viewpoint of Orphan Andy's is always the same: Meh.

Service is usually on point, food is always basic diner food...and not that there's anything wrong with that...it's just...basic.
author: Trav M.

description: First off this place is open 24/7 so that alone is amazing. Second off you can order breakfast food 24 hours a day, also amazing. I have come here countless times with so many different people and we always leave totally satisfied and beyond stuffed. My favorite is the banana chocolate chip hot cakes...they're to die for! I mean it's a huge stack of banana, and chocolate chips and pancakes. They're especially good at 2 am after a long night. Other notable dishes are their burgers. They're all delicious especially if you pair them with nice crispy onion rings! My other go to dish is the typical breakfast dish - 2 eggs, toast, bacon and breakfast potatoes. The servings are massive so come prepared to feast!!! Tip: the weekend line is crazy, come prepared to wait. I normally head over before I'm hungry, get my name on the list and then hang around outside and enjoy the sunshine a little. That way I'm not starving while I wait and instead generally am seated by the time my hunger really starts kicking in! Trust me you don't want to be waiting in line with your tummy rumbling - although this place is totally worth it if that's what ends up happening :)
author: Sami F.

description: I've had plenty of meals here, but never reviewed it...so here goes:  this place is one of the best restaurants in SF!  It's not fancy but it's clean, the food is delicious, and it's open 24hrs.  My sandwich today was a tuna melt and it was killer!  They are also popular for their breakfasts...
author: Mike L.

description: Been coming here for years but never go back.... A case of reverse discrimination?  My girl and I along with another couple stop by for a late dinner after seeing the film festival at the Castro. . I was immediately informed that there was no room for us becuase everyone had just sat down.... Thought he was joking I asked all at once? . I said no worries we wait..... After a, dirty look from the waiter I asked would you rather we leave and his response was yes..... Fuckk him and Fuck this restaurants..... I want n apology..... I guess we weren't gay enough for him.... Owners I'm offended
author: Sam T.

description:
I wasn't able to sit in this restaurant because I wasn't white. I will never patron this white privilege haven. This restaurant will state that I was another angry minority, but I was just another patron craving fries. This haven represents everything I loathe about LGBT businesses. Just because I complain about disparate treatment, DOES NOT warrant unequal treatment. If you want another white privilege haven, frequent this restaurant. If you don't, go anywhere elsewhere. 

Everything I hate about the LGBT community in one restaurant.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Really cute go-to place for when you need grub at obscure hours. 24/7 diner with waitstaff that kind of just... Deal with you. My friend and I were somewhat ignored, thought tended on, and had awkward waits while they chatted up with local customers and regulars. It's cool that they're so close to these people but really, we just want to order! If it takes more than 10 minutes, I'm grumpy.

The food itself... Not that great. Almost unbearable hotcakes and disgusting maple syrup that makes eating it even harder. So-so omelets and edible french toast. The prices, though fair, don't match the quality of the food.

The two stars is for the cool atmosphere, being a 24/7 joint, and for the ceiling - it's quite pretty. And maybe for the super tight jeans the waiters wear, but I don't know how much a girl can appreciate that on a man she can never get...
author: Colleen M.

description: Good spot to take in sf and Castro but servers are a Lil rude ijs . Other then that during pride this is the spot so I'm going to stop complaining lol
author: Monique D.

description:
I really enjoyed concluding our night out with a satisfying meal from Orphan Andy's....
We were lucky enough to get a table for 4 right away....
The place is cozy and vibrant! Feels very homey!

There were so much to choose from, from the menu! But last night, the word Gravy caught my eye, and i started to drool. So i got the Chicken smothered in Gravy which came with fries and minestrone soup. It was indeed, YUMMY!

A friend of mine got french toast...and harhar.... got sick when his order came. So, MORE for us...and OMG. to die for. it was sooo good. I'm not really a big fan of cinnamon, so I rarely get French toasts from restaurants. Orphan Andy's french toast has just the right amount of cinnamon and it's not too overpowering that i could have finished the entire plate PLUS my chicken and gravy.

The service was wonderful...the server took time to chit chat with us and ask how we're doing even though the place was really packed.
author: Monica H.

description:
It's a bit unfair that hole-in-the-wall diners tend to have an automatic disadvantage in the quest for five star reviews. I personally think Andy's has a ton of character and personality, and that goes a long way in my book (there's nothing that bores me more than a cookie-cutter dining experience, which is why I'll never leave SF). So yes, maybe the food is "greasy", but sometimes that exactly what I'm looking for. Don't judge me.

It had been at least 5 years since I'd been here (until this weekend). Although I do remember from my last visit that my pancakes were perfectly fluffy and delicious. I returned again this weekend with my two sisters, and was surprised to find the same older gentleman taking my order. That doesn't happen very often, especially in big cities like SF where people come and go so frequently. So that was a sign of good things to come :)

We sat at a booth towards the back and were promptly greeted. I went with the turkey club with a side of potato salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/6BMxNLbCSQIe72nYGiJBXA?select=Jb04Lrxo7Msmw791u-epFg). My sisters ordered burgers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/6BMxNLbCSQIe72nYGiJBXA?select=_Hham08Lgev-OFUnQq_Xlg). My turkey club came out and it was STACKED. Half of it was turkey (score!). The club was cut into four pieces, and the bread was toasted perfectly and wasn't too crispy so as to make it hard to take a bite out of the sandwich. But the big shocker was the potato salad...it was freakin' delicious! It must have been the seasoning, because potato salad is really nothing without it. I think I tasted paprika. In any case, I wished I could have ordered a pint of it to take home with me!

I also like that the staff was appropriately attentive - my sisters and I were yammering on and on, so they took that as a queue that we would be there for a while and just came by occassionally to offer up drink refills. It's a small place and I know seating is hard to come by, especially on a Saturday afternoon, so I was pleased that the staff didn't make us feel rushed at all. The bill came to $40 including tax, for three people. Not bad at all.

Next time, I'll have to come back for a French Toast fix! ((drool))
author: Mariela D.

description:
Looking for a hot spot to go to and changing my mind from a late night open til 6am club to this spot I just fell in love with by the name alone. NEON OPEN 24 HOURS SIGN! how could you go wrong?  A bit on the small side about 5 booths and 7 dining bar stools, but compensated for the restaurant size by the food portions.  You definitely get what you paid for weather you order a fatty burger, chilli cheese fries, or a stack of  pancakes.  YO CANNOT GO WRONG.  

The service is sweet and cute just like their baileys cheesecake.  From what I've heard this diner is just as poppin' during the AM and daytime hours as when I was there, from about 2-4am. 

A good spot for the drunchies or if you wanna grab a bite to eat while exploring the beauties around CASTRO.

Love love love it all.  Will return again and again.
author: Hazel K.

description:
WOW!  This place used to be one of my favorite places to eat in the Castro - even though you have to deal with the worst service ever.  I'll get to that. 

I've lived in this neighborhood for 8 years and have eaten at Orphan Andy's at least  3 dozen times.  The food used to be so good for a decent price.  But, alas, the last 4 times I have eaten here, it's just been a waste of my time and money.

They claim it's still the same cook it has been for 6 or 7 years, and maybe he's too comfortable, because this morning when I got my "omellete" it was a welllllll-done pile of egg on top of a pile of chewy non-edible bacon (and I can always eat BACON!) and I literally had to use a KNIFE to cut thru the egg!  It was so disgusting! 1 bite and I was done.  

And if that's not bad enough, the SERVICE!  OMG!  Since the 1st time I went to Orphan Andy's the service always mortified me.  I literally couldn't believe that these 2 assholes that run service in the mornings could be so condescending to me and to everyone!  I still came back because I liked the food.

I couldn't take it anymore after today.  They were SO rude to my table - as usual- and to a nice old man who came in to order take-out.  His food probably took 30 min to get (and ours took almost 40 min to get!) and they just kept telling him he was in the way and to move - instead of offering for him to sit at the EMPTY bar.  I couldn't handle it anymore, so I asked if he'd like to sit at our table while we both wait for our really bad food with our extremely bad service.  I also think they don't like women/lesbians - because they tend to be very nice to cute little gay boys that come in - seating them immediately and giving them a warm smile with a menu and a glass of water, whereas, we had to ask for a menu and had to ask for water twice!   

These guys have got to be some of the most bitter human beings I've ever met in my life.  And now the food tastes like the service.  I'M DONE and NEVER going back  again!
author: Amie B.

description:
Im always here with wonderfull people. 

I seem to always get the protein platter with a chicken breast/eggs/and cottage cheese! Got to keep my womanly figure! lmao
author: Andrew V.

description:
I was in the area looking for a bite while my dog got groomed. I decided on this place because I wanted breakfast food. My experience probably would have been better had there not been a singing bafoon working there. The rest of the staff seemed quite normal and looked a little embarrassed by this idiot. He was playing music on the jukebox (fun stuff. Lady gaga, Amy Winehouse, etc) and singing while posing on all of the booths and chairs and then taking a smoke break every 15 minutes . I understand he was having a good time, but it boggled my Mind that this guy was getting paid to do this while all the other employees were behind the counter or in the kitchen working. I could tell all the other customers were uncomfortable too because they avoided him by staring at their phones or newspapers. 
My food was okay, not fabulous but I enjoyed the French toast. 
Bottom line? They need to fire the little starlet trying to make a name for himself that  is greeting all the customers as "sexy". My rating would go up another star or two.
author: Shmev R.

description: Decent, got the norm chili cheese fries. Over priced but I guess they gotta pay the bills. Servers are almost always mediocre at best. In desperate need of smiling servers who actually like people...
author: Adrian F.

description: High quality diner with great, casual service. They have a great classic Monte Christo sandwich!
author: V M.

description: Always going to be a place to go when it's super late and everything is closed. Not because of its hours and convenience but just happens to be the GO-TO place after a long night roaming the city. Good food and service.
author: Sarah M.

description:
If the Afterworld offers 24 hours to return to Earth and enjoy my favorite places one last time, I'll come here at 5AM. Maybe I'd finally give the Sweetie Pie strawberry omelette a try at last.

Best ambiance, best service (if you're not a jerk, OK?), and best greasy goodness ever. 24/7!!!

(((BTW, I'm definitely NOT a cute gay boy, and they STILL treat me like a princess!!!)))
author: Jaina D.

description:
The main thing going for this place is that they are open 24hrs. Other than that, the food is so-so. Basically your deep-fried variety.

Friendly service. Didn't see anyone cute to eye-flirt with when I was there, but that's not their fault. It was a Monday night.
author: F. M.

description:
Located at the corner of Castro and Market, this casual diner gets a lot of foot traffic from commuters.  I was one of them.  As a regular commuter that stops by the area,  my first visit was also my last. 

I stepped in for a late breakfast.  Less than half the seats at this cramped diner were occupied with single individuals.  Short of being greeted by ANY of the wait staff, I grabbed myself a menu and started browsing.  After 6 minutes, when the head waiter, a sloppily-dressed balding guy with white hair, finally decided to acknowledge me, he hollered "Just sit tight, ok?!!"  His short-tempered tone was not a good way to start off my experience as a hungry diner. Nevertheless, I brushed it off and kept waiting.

Finally, after another 6 minutes waiting, the waiter came over.  Before he could utter anything polite like 'How are you?'  or 'What can I get for you?', he barked "Put your foot under the table, PLEASE!!"  I was seated at one of the table/booths along the wall and had my left foot inched toward the center isle.  I wasn't blocking anyone; my foot wasn't hindering the walkway.  After barking at me, he exhaled to blow off his steam before reluctantly asking "What can I get you?"

Geeze!  Somebody needs to teach these bimbos about customer service! I know I'm not dining at the Ritz or a chain restaurant, but for a place that serves mediocre to average food, it'd be in the staff and business owner's best interest NOT to create such hostile environment, even before a diner can order!!  

I'll NEVER stop by again; I'd rather starve!
author: Honest J.

description: Why are you asking me? Because I thought you worked here! Not a job this guy should still hold. My poached eggs in bowl were ugly but not as ugly as the guy serving them! The young guy who helped me did his best best but the old guy was horrible. Awful! Never ever had such rude ugly service. You can no longer think that's okay! The way you talked to your kitchen! The way you talked to your guests! Really really horrible! Glad I don't know your name.
author: Armando R.

description: I love this place, I come here once a week at least! The French toast and the pancakes are unreal!
author: Seán O.

description: Got the worst service from a waiter that could care less than to service his table, but was more interested in making out with his boyfriend. He was too busy with making out that the other waiter had to give us our check. If you want to have a good dinning experience than this is not the place for you.
author: Drew C.

description: It's open 24 hours and the banana pancakes are the best!!!
author: Damian G.

description:
I usually come here and get a quick bite to eat after work. That won't be happening anymore. 
Today as usual, two servers were arguing with each other, and then with the cook, and the one server was trying to explain they are a team and gotta work together. She's right! You're a team, pull it together, get the job done. I know, I work in the industry for a fine dining restaurant in the city. So after this, minding my own business, eating, I look up to see one server, he knows who he is, I won't mention his name that starts with a C, was filling up drinks from the fountain and was staring at me shaking his head and had the most evil look on his face. Is this cause I ordered a decadent plate? Because I am husky? Or did I say or do something to offend you? I never talk when I am there, I just wanna eat and be left alone and not hear people argue. All this made me feel insecure and judged and I finished my meal and left. 

Seems the Castro attitude and judgments have really festered enough and driven locals like me away. Thanks for ruining my dinner Chad!
author: William D.

description:
Oui-
Diner, Breakfast, Castro, Pancakes
Service pas super.
author: M S.

description: Best breakfast in San Francisco. Their chef is a master at cooking eggs. I am very picky about eggs and he cooked them exactly perfect. French toast and pancakes are yummy. Wait staff are spunky and awesome. I try to come here at least once everytime I visit SF. They are right in the heart of the Castro district. Perfect location to start your day.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Normally I really do not like this place simply because of the Staff and their attitudes.  Mainly at Nite...
However I think last nite they got an customer back. Service was friendly and the food was outstanding! 
Order the double cheeseburger which I have been craving all day and it satisfied my hunger. 
Ate there with friends, had a good time.
5 happy to be a customer again Stars!
author: Anthony J G.

description:
Any place that manages to stay open all hours of the day deserve major props. But to stay open late with fantastic service, that deserves an award or something. The staff here at this greasy spoon is a wild bunch who are the nicest people on earth. It's as if they've been place here to nurture your inebriated ass to soberness with some tender loving grub and nice conversations.

The food is greasy and affordable, exactly what you'd expect from a diner or soup kitchen. I ordered the chili fries because I just wanted something to munch on, but was surprised to find a gigantic plate of the stuff on the counter when I got back from the restroom that's located through the kitchen and downstairs. It was a beautiful sight and could've fed three other people, but it didn't taste as good as it looked. It was much too mild and didn't have the kick of spices or color like good chili is supposed to have. I suppose you can't have it all! The good thing is, you can tell it's housemade and not just bulk-bought chili from a can. Andrew got the chicken tenders sandwich, which I didn't have any of, but it looked delicious. I should've asked for a bite!

+bar/counter seating
+booth seating
+jukebox
author: Jennifer W.

description: It had been a while since I had been to orphan Andy's and let's just say Costco is doing really well thanks to the business orphan Andy's is giving them. Other than the coffee, everything else along with the friendly service has gone out the window. I know times are tough for businesses in the city but, does quality of product necessarily have to suffer? If you build it, they will come... Take a dump in the middle of your plate and maybe not everyone would like to dip their pita in that hummus. Get what I'm saying?
author: Aabid K.

description:
Was in San Frabcisco for Folsom Street Fair and ate there three or four times for breakfast. I think they called what I ordered "Big Two". It was two eggs, two slices of bacon and two sausage links. With this I had french Toast. It was great, almost top much to eat. The staff was very nice and offered free refills for my Cokes. 

I have eaten here previously when in San Francisco and have always been happy with my meal. The breakfast is the best though. Last year when I was in there once a waiter was rude but I think there was a miscommunication. I am partially deaf and I heard him say something about me being rude. I either didn't hear what he said or didn't understand. Part of it was my fault, I wasn't wearing my hearing aids.

Unless you arrive in the early morning or late at night parking is a problem everywhere in San Francisco. 

Not a huge cafe, very retro decor but a great place to eat.
author: Mike D.

description:
Great spot for a late night meal. I went here with a few of my friends at around 1am on a Thursday and there was a line out the door. Luckily we only had to wait about 15 minutes and the waitstaff were extremely nice and friendly.
I had the grilled cheese with bacon which was delicious. The bacon was perfectly crispy and they definitely know how to make a classic grilled cheese. The fries that came on the side were pretty average and were unfortunately cold, but they weren't terrible. 
The only thing that was off-putting was that everything seems a little dirty. The menus and tables felt sort of sticky or greasy, but it was worth it for that grilled cheese.
author: Cara K.

description:
I used to work in the Castro when I first moved to the area. 

Orphan Andy's quickly became my stand-by place for late night french toast.

The food is standard. Nothing remarkable. In fact  - it's pretty forgettable. I was going to paint this review with yummy descriptions about said french toast - but my taste-buds are pulling blanks. Never a great sign.

But what this place lacks in taste - it makes up for with their on point hours, and their cute booth seating. I am sucker for late night - twenty four hour eats - and after a long night - there is nothing better - than cozy-ing up with some friends in an intimate red booth. 

My advice: don't come here for breakfast or during the day. There are FAR better spots in the area for quality morning grub. But late at night - when places are shutting shop- Orphan Andy's is a lovely place to come for inebriated conversations and food.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: amazing! love the food, adore the service. will visit again and again
author: Kym M.

description: If you're looking for a late night meal this place is pretty good and very nice quiet and homey after a long night. The severs are always very nice and talkative
author: Genah M.

description: To keep it short and sweet, this place is the best! Great service and food no matter the time! This will be my new go to place in the city
author: Allie V.

description: It doesn't speak well of me that I have continued to patronize Orphan Andy's for years, although the food quality and the service are clearly lacking; but, it is a rare diner in the Castro and is open 24 hours.  The breakfast menu is acceptable (although, for my last visit I was served eggs with the whites still dripping from my fork.  Gross.), the service is okay, as long as you don't get the Bitter Old Queen whose surliness is less than entertaining. The bitch actually kicked my foot and told me to get out of her way!  If I had been dining alone I would have charged the server with assault. I've forgiven myself for being slow to respond to operant conditioning; but, I've finally moved on.   Prices have gone up, and the quality of food and service seems to be sliding. It's a little difficult to slide too far, when you are already nearing rock bottom.
author: Cullen H.

description: The service staff was super super rude when I walked in and sat down. My two friends were smoking outside and I took the only available table. A gentlemen in a black hoodie with shaggy brown hair came to me to tell me that I needed more people to sit there. I guess I interrupted him when I told him I was waiting on 2 people, because he said quite obnoxiously "excuse me excuse me excuse me" and continued on 'proving his point'. I know it's late at night but I'm not drunk and I don't need to be disrespected by a  bad as the service. Well our waiter Bruce is nice. He can stay
author: Kathryn G.

description: The food is great and so was the table service. However, the place is so tiny and cramped, especially the nasty bathroom. The employees in the kitchen are creepy too.
author: Jackie K.

description:
God, I love the freaking Castro.

We were scouting around after our chiropractor appointment this week for a place with some inexpensive but yummy food.  After "thinking about" a couple of places that we saw, we happened upon Orphan Andy's.  I had seen this place some years before, but never went in.  The prices were a bit cheaper than some of the other spots, so we went in.

Nice.  This is a greasy spoon in the best sense of the word.  Yup, the hamburgers and fries are wonderfully oily and delicious.  Not the kind of place you go to for health food, but if you're in the mood for a great burger or sandwich (like my wife's terrific reuben) no matter what the time of day and night, this is the place.  My daughter didn't like the salad--she said there was too much garlic, vinegar and lemon.  She did like the chicken tenders though, as did we.

Great ambiance and service here.  The tables are OLD, the pictures on the wall are cool, and the bathroom is really tiny but spotless.  Awesome spot to eat and well worth a repeat visit.  I haven't yet found a restaurant in this neighborhood that I didn't like and Orphan Andy's continues the trend.
author: Matthew D.

description: It's probably great if you've been drinking. One of the servers was pretty cool.  The other one had a horrible attitude. Maybe this is supposed to be part of the charm but I wasn't feeling it.  He was snippy with everyone. Food was goodish. Pancakes tasted like box mix, so nothing too special. Potatoes were the highlight.  Everything else wasn't much better than I could make.
author: Bobby H.

description:
The food is good but the service leaves a lot to be desired.  

We stopped by for lunch recently and ordered at the counter (tables were all filled up).  I had an omelette, my wife had a salad.  Nothing fancy in either dish that would take special preparation.  

A few minutes later, two guys took the next two stools to the left.  In the next 20 minutes they ordered (regular lunch entrees), ate, paid and left.  We still hadn't been served and apparently the waiter wasn't paying attention.  I finally asked him where our food was and he said that, yeah, he should go check.  He went into the kitchen (about 5 steps away) and came back and said that something on one of our orders needed special prep and I'm thinking like, maybe the eggs or the lettuce?  

Anyway, our plates finally showed up about 5 minutes later.  The food was good, the portions generous, the prices though a little high not unusual for SF.  But clearly the kitchen wasn't processing orders very well and our waiter, though he was serving just a few feet of counter and could see whose plates were coming out of the kitchen and whose weren't, wasn't paying much attention.  

Based on this experience I'm not sure I would go back.  There are plenty of other good restaurants in the neighborhood that know how to treat their customers.
author: Michael R.

description: Only place I've found in San Francisco that serves chicken fingers similar to those I am used to getting in Buffalo, NY.  My boyfriend and I absolutely loved our experience here and can't wait to go again!!!
author: Daphne W.

description: Great little spot. Wait staff was personable and attentive. Excellent diner feel - bacon burger was delicious - handcrafted angus beef patty. Yum!
author: Jessica P.

description:
1. I think the food is good (for diner-type food) - I liked the banana pancakes with butter and maple syrup I had last night... yum!
2. They have coffee... I like it ;)
3. People nice!
4. Boys drunk and easy! (ummm... yeah)
5. When there's a wait, at least you get your name on a list, so it's not hard to know where you stand and how long the wait might be
6. Open reeaaalllly late (maybe 24 hours?) - and when you want to hang out with someone in the early early morning hours, where else are you going to go in the Castro?
author: Jason B.

description:
The food is nothing special, but a reliable tasty diner with a great waitstaff.
Go expecting greasyspoon-diner cuisine and you'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: Michelle L.

description:
We were on a tight schedule, and there was no wait, so we came in for breakfast.  The service was very nice.  The food was decent.

Tintin had the stuffed french toast, and the portion was so enormous, he could only eat half.  I had a tuna melt with tomato.  I liked that it had hard boiled egg whites in it, but I had to take out half the tuna to make it easier to eat.  

Prices are average, so it was pretty reasonable for the amount of food we got.
author: Seong P.

description: Came for a late dinner & ordered burgers. I had mine with a side of creamy cottage cheese. This is your average American diner with friendly staff & food that does that job. It's near a ton of bars so expect the drunkies to stumble in.
author: Catheria S.

description:
First of all: Open 24 hours.  That's just amazing.  

Came across this place for the first time tonight...thank goodness because I was so hungry and there were no places to eat after 11pm.  

Got the regular hamburger.  It was decent.  The orange juice was freshly squeezed.  Service was good. Chad was really nice! 

 Overall, it was a cute place and it's good for a quick, inexpensive, late-night meal.
author: Juliana K.

description:
Great 24/7 diner in the castro.   Servers are always friendly and good diner food at a reasonable price.

My favorite items are the Banana Chocolate Chip pancakes if I want breakfast food or the Chicken Tender sandwich if I want a sandwich.

Portions are very big.  When I order the pancakes, I save the $1 and get a stack of 2 instead of 3.   Not a place to go if you are on a diet or watching your carb intake:

Great location if you want a place to eat at after or before going to the castro bars.
author: Mike S.

description: Always been a fan of this place. Great food all night, quick service, and great atmosphere!
author: Drew N.

description:
After being mobbed by the local news reporters I "B-Lined" it to "L-O-A" to tame my hunger. Right away the two gents behind the counter Shane & Steven were courteous and easy on the eyes...they were making me laugh with their humor as the news reporters were sticking their microphone in my face. Anyways I always order the "Chicken breast, two eggs, and two pancakes" breakfast entree this hit the spot and I left L-O-A satisfied with my meal, the service, but most of all the eye candy!
Best always, Russell H.
author: Russell H.

description:
3.5 stars.

It's great to have a place in the city serving food all night long. On top of that, breakfast food! Whoo-hoo.

I got the chili omelette -- the fried eggs they use for the omelettes are legit and very very tasty. The eggs just automatically makes everything else taste good! Apparently my friends all loved the omelette with bacon and cream cheese in it. I checked out the bacon and it was very crispy and very nice, but bacon makes everything tastes good anyway so I suspect that's cheating ;)

For the side, I ordered home fries and toast. That's where the downfall is. My homefries were so bland I abandoned eating it. If only it were as tasty as the eggs!

The service was ok. Nothing spectacular. Overall I enjoyed my experience and would come here just for the eggs again.
author: Alice C.

description: This place gets 0 stars for this most horrific service I have ever experienced in my life... And we didn't even eat there!!!! My fiancé and I walk in and are standing waiting for a table. We are greeted by a very friendly older man who says it'll be a minute.  After a few minutes of standing two guys get up from the bar and we proceed to sit down as there's not a lot of standing room in the place. Then a skinny dude with a blue feathered earring comes over to clean the spots and proceeds to berate us about not waiting until the bar was cleaned to sit down. We felt so uncomfortable that we just got up and left. It was so uncalled for, and the worst display of an angry person taking it out on paying customers that I have ever seen. Whoever is still employing that guy is just chasing business out his door because it's clear from other reviews that this is not the first incident.
author: Lauren C.

description: Love Orphan Andy's. My partner and I have been coming here since the mid 1980's and it's the one piece of San Francisco that seems to never change. The owner must never leave because he is always there to greet you with both snark and smile no matter the time or day/night you visit.
author: Nick W.

description: The owners are lovely people. A fun couple. Nice place to hang out with friends or before club/bars/ drinking lol below the market price food.  Typical American greasy food. Get ready to gain some weight.
author: Alanda B.

description: So these people were pretty cool in hipster kind of way. The service was so so but the food was really good , but then again i came after a long night at the bar and truly forgot i even stopped until i seen the leftover on the floor of my hotel room. Goodtimes
author: adrian r.

description: Stopped by here after a night of dancing in the Castro. I had the fried chicken which was good! My hubby had the veggie burger with huge onion rings, also good. We sat at the bar since none of the tables were free (it's a small-ish place). Our service was pretty good no complaints. Menu is pretty extensive and very much diner style. We'll be back!
author: Vol T.

description: There's never a time I'm in the Castro and I don't go here. Despite the drunken patrons that flood the restaurant, the food is delicious....especially at 3 AM after the clubs and you happen to be one of the drunken patrons I mentioned earlier. (Yes I have eaten here sober before......like once...). Anyways, I am NOT a french toast fan believe it or not but everytime I go there...I get what? FRENCH TOAST! I love their French Toast and their staff is always super friendly and sweet to me, probably because they never had to throw me out. But yes...yummy yummy yummy! Get their french toast!!
author: Heather S.

description:
Not for kids? I don't know how the readership has figured that out. Orphan Andy's is perfect for kids, who don't hew to our old-fogie schedules, who love visual stimulation, and who love people.

We've been bringing our kids to Orphan Andy's for eleven years now, and the staff have been absolutely wonderful (hi, Mike and Woody!!). The chocolate-chip pancakes with chocolate chips cooked inside and more on the side never ceases to please the offspring, as does the crispy bacon omelette.

Kids, bring your adults to Orphan Andy's (and the Castro) and let their withered and enfeebled minds expand.
author: Michael S.

description: Great food horrible service. Had the bacon cheeseburger and it was simply fantastic. The guy managing 'the line' was a total bitch and I think there's a reason 99% of restaurants manage seating by taking names. Likely because it works...? Idk trying to remember who was in line first seems inefficient and begging for confusion. I won't be back unless it's my only option.
author: Andrew P.

description: This place has terrible service....the waiter was completely rude and had a bad attitude. Our food took forever to come out and we were considerate of the fact that it was busy, but every time we asked for little things like getting more water the waiter was completely snobby and made us feel guilty. The food was not great and cold cause it came to us at different times. Then we waited for the check for 45 minutes and when we finally asked the waiter for it, he was again rude..... Ignored us and continued to clean tables. Awful, awful experience! The only reason I am giving this one star is because I'm not allowed to leave 0 stars.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I love diners, don't get me wrong. I also love restaurants that are open 24/7. So my roommate and I decide to go out on a Thursday night to grab drinks, and afterward are looking for a snack. The ambiance in this small place is cute--definitely like a 50's diner. We were craving fried chicken (yes, one of those nights), so we ordered chicken strips. When they came, we were SO disappointed. Listen, I would have been happier with McDonald's chicken nuggets over these dry strips. 

In retrospect, there are so many other places around there that are open 24/7, I would recommend going elsewhere. Or at the least, not ordering that dish because it was not impressive at all.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
Go to just check out the bathroom! You have to walk through a greasy floored kitchen, past a stove with boiling water/potatoes, down some slippery steps into what can only be described as an indoor outhouse. 

Food is pretty good and they have always accommodated special requests. 

Service is hit or miss but it is what it is....... typical SF B.S. at times--attitude and rudeness from some servers. The guy in the shorts tried to correct my pronunciation of an Italian cheese I wanted with my omelet-- "it's pro-vo-lo-nee" said the shorts wearing server. 
Umm, no--it's really pronounced "pro-vo-lo-nay".   Stick to serving diner food, hon. 
I like their soups!
author: Thomas D.

description: Packed with late night animals. Fast and friendly service, right across the street from the Harvey Milk something or other. Just the kind of spot to grab breakfast at 3am.
author: Shane N.

description:
Great place for breakfast.  Many many choices and great door. Mustard is awesome and they want their customers to enjoy their meal.  They even have an option of chicken sausage for breakfast!  This is great for those of us that do not eat pork!  

All of the food is awesome - highly recommend!
author: Herb B.

description: Over priced for a grease pit hole in the wall. Ordered the bleu cheese burger it's my go to at any diner that serves it.  FAIL !!!!!  It was grease grease grease charred cheese burnt patty and grease!!!! Need I mention the server was to busy flirting with another table to give a damn about me. Won't be back.
author: Narada J.

description:
Went here for a late breakfast, had the 4 pcs of fried chicken and 4 hot cakes (pancakes). The pancakes were very filling and the chicken was very god (with some hot sauce). It was cheap so I didn't expect Michelin-restaurant-quality but the food was good and the servers were nice. Everything took a little longer than normal because they were training a new employee, but that's part of business so i don't blame them! 
The only thing I didn't really like  is that of the 4 pcs of chicken , 2 were very small!
I'll definitely come here again!
author: Frans B.

description: Twice I've been here, staffs attitudes make it a bad diner.  Kind of misogynist.  Food is ok.  They need a woman to fill in the blanks though.  Doesn't matter if mtf, whatever, just that kind of nurturing service or energy.   I get the orphan andy infringement on Annie to make it their thing.. but as an establishment needs some feminine to warm it up, give it diner life
author: C L.

description:
Little Oprhan Tranny's is by far the bitchiest late-night diner ever. The service is always lackluster and everybody that works there seems to hate everyone. Your better off taking yourself to Sparky's which is bigger, and the people serving you are nice. Better food selection, and no attitude in your food.

One time at the end of dinner I asked a server to divide the bill in half and was given a calculater and told to figure it out myself. Are you fucking serious?

Seriously, Little Orphan Tranny's may as well take a big fat shit on a plate and serve it to you and charge you, because that's exactly what your getting, a plate full of SHIT!
author: Gazza D.

description:
Expensive prices, food is just ok, and the worst..: the RUDEST service I have had since forever. I can't believe that these people treat you like s**t, when you are paying them to get the food and they are earning the tips. Yes, this is the Castro, but you should put your bloody bitchy attitude somewhere else and treat people with some respect.

I am talking about the darker guy, probably Mexican-american, who was working the late night shift of the Sunday Pride. Seriously man, go somewhere else where you don't have to deal with customers.

I am never coming back here because of you.

I just wished the owner read this and changed the service. He could make a lot of extra money, since this is the only place open late at night. But hey, these guys are making themselves a reputation for offering the most f***ing rude service in the area. Hence, avoid at all cost unless you are literally DESPERATE and willing to pay to be treated like s**t.
author: Leon S K.

description: Came in here for lunch on a Saturday, sat at the counter and the waiter recommended the turkey club.  It was easily the best turkey club I've had in SF!  The people working there were awesome and really funny as well, the customers were an interesting mix of tourists and locals all looking some simple and good comfort food.  I would certainly go back, and since this place is 24 hrs I bet they get a lot of people coming in at 2am looking for burgers and chili fries.
author: Mackenzie B.

description:
We went here after going out to the bars. After waiting in line for 30 minutes, we decided it would be faster to just order takeout and eat at one of our apartments.

To quote a previous Yelper's review: "Blonde facial-haired waiter was the rudest person I have literally ever met." 

This pretty much sums up what happened next. I asked the guy if they did takeout to which he curtly replied "No", RIGHT as he hands another customer a big bag of food to go. All the while he doesn't so much as look at me. I understand it was busy, but I will definitely not be coming back to a place that clearly doesn't want my business.
author: Sean C.

description:
What a shame that Andy's can't get zero stars, because even one star feels like a reward for crappy service.

On previous visits the food and service have been OK.  Not great, but 1AM good.

Tonight's server was so very rude (yes, you in the grey polo with red logo) that I got up and left rather than order.  Just couldn't stomach giving any money to a business (or server) that would treat customers in such a rude & patronizing way.

Don't assume that your customers (yes, customers - look it up) are deaf and can't hear your comments about them.  Or - if you're gonna talk crap about them - don't expect any sort of tip.  Ever.

Any place that would employ you and your attitude is one that won't be getting any more business from me or anyone I know.
author: Rick C.

description: Whoever wrote that review about the chocolate chip and banana pancakes got me addicted.  I tried them and they were out of this world.  I have been here several times now and one thing I can say is that the food is of consistent quality.  It is exactly what one should expect for diner food and especially one that's open 24 hours.  The staff is cool and prices are fair.  No real complants.. the only drawback is that it is tiny and it can be hard to get a seat but that's not really their fault.
author: Sin F.

description:
World's greatest diner
Sells the world's greatest pancakes.
And yet, I heart boobs.
author: Josh G.

description:
sadly, when it comes to 24-hour diners in SF, the pickings are pretty slim, but this is one of the better ones for sure. used to mix this place up with sparky's on church, but the places couldn't be more different.

everything at orphan andy's is reasonably fresh and made from scratch (to the extent that one would expect from a diner), and it definitely tastes like it too.
author: Mark A.

description: Rude service and bad food. Classic combo.
author: MIke S.

description:
Cute little diner, perfect for a late night slice of apple pie.

pie was pretty good and my gf loved her chocolate cafe.  small spot with cute decor. could get crowded easily. waiter was friendly but staff seemed a little stressed out :-)
author: Coco J.

description:
The pie a la mode is more a la mode than pie if you look at the picture I have uploaded. My buddy had their banana pancake and after having a bite he had his O-face
The staff was prompt and very friendly, I will definitely be back when I'm up here and don't know what yo eat in the late hours since this place is 24hrs i'll definitely have this high on my list.
author: James S.

description:
A neat little place to grab some grub, especially when it's really late. The food consists of your typical diner, all-American dishes. I tried the Sloppy Joe omelet because I've never had one before but when I thought about the gooey goodness of a Sloppy Joe mix inside an egg (without a bun, so it's not so sloppy!) I had to try it.

It was really good! However, the home fries stole the glory. Not your typical home fries, but they were really, really good.

The decorations are neat inside. It's a little crammed, but that's my only real complaint. The service was friendly and prompt.

This definitely beats other 24-hour diners in the city. I'd just hate to think about how packed this place is after 2 AM on a Saturday.
author: Sara K.

description: Come here if you want a beautiful place and NO RESPECT AT ALL. Terrible and rude service.
author: Ana Paula B.

description: The diner is in a great position (as stated by an earlier reviewer) and a window booth lets you see the world go by.  The meals were very generous the philly steak and chicken tender sandwiches were delicious.  The staff were friendly and helped us with directions to find our next port of call.
author: Davin C.

description:
Super cute diner open 24 hours. Amazing!
The food isn't the best, nothing you wouldn't expect. Came here for some 4am mozzarella sticks. It was bumpin'. Definitely a fun late night crowd, but I'm not sure I'd here before midnight or... sober.
author: christine c.

description:
Orphan Andy's is one of my favourite all-night diners in the city. I'd been a number of time before moving away, and it was one of the first places I ate upon returning to the city. 

The food is tasty--comfort food in a cozy and whimsical atmosphere. (And by whimsical, we mean festooned with posters of naked men riding dolphins.) The whole restaurant feels warm and inviting, especially important for when you get those late night munchies and need something tasty, stat. The wait staff is gregarious and friendly. 

One of my favourites is the apple-stuffed french toast. Very yummy! Still a favourite. And I recently tried the biscuits and gravy after developing a mad craving. (You can get this alone, or with fried chicken, or with pork, or even steak.) The breakfast options are plentiful, and I've yet to feel disappointed after a meal. 

Probably the only times to avoid this joint are right in the midst of Pride (so packed! But maybe you like it that way!) and it can be crowded Sunday mornings as well.
author: Lis M.

description: Go here to see Bruce. He's so wonderful. At 2:30am on Sunday morning when you are coming back to the real world and you're like "ah I just want....... a hamburger? with pickles?" he'll make you feel very welcome. The burger was MASSIVE and kind of flavorless. The Jack wasn't pepper-y. The bacon was bacon. And the fries were soggy. I'll get a waffle next time as long as Bruce is there. And he has cute friends.
author: Megan S.

description: Out of All the American Dinners in SF this is the best one open 24hrs. The food quality is good and the staff is friendly,good place to hang out with friends or to simply strike a good conversation.
author: Alex V.

description: Given the lack of late night food options in SF we decided to give Orphan Andy's a try around 11pm. We walked in hopeful and walked out disgusted. The turkey reuben contained strange-tasting sauerkraut and thousand island dressing. I'm not sick the day after so I guess it hadn't gone bad--as much as it tasted that way. The potato salad must have come from a can. Another one of us had a "spicy chicken caesar salad." The only thing caesar about it was the romaine. Other than that it was a strange and unpleasant drizzle of a thickened soy dressing and plastic caesar dressing. Topped with powdered imitation parmesan and boxed baby "croutons." The chicken part of the salad was dry and awful. Overall it was a salty mess. It's not bargain-priced but even if it were we'll be staying far, far away. I suppose the 2am crowd is the only reason this place is still around.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Want to see a bitter queen in her natural habitat? Slide on over to a stool at the counter at Orphan Andy's on weekdays, say about 7 in the morning. The Salvadoran cooks in the back are standing around not doing much. The waiter, tall, older gentleman gray hair and glasses wearing shorts. He walks around imitating a short order cook and he even has the nerve to say "babe" at the end of his sentences. "Babe" as in "hon" or something folksy or sassy.

Ordered the diced ham and scrambled eggs, home fries and sourdough toast on a crisp Friday morning. Got coffee too. Maybe it's because I wasnt too much into the morning chatter or maybe I didnt say "no thanks" when this guy came barreling in with his coffee pot for the refill later, but he didnt seem to like my atttiude,

I didn't like his food. The eggs were supposed to be runny or "easy" and they had clumps of egg whites so they werent properly mixed or scrambled. The home fries were dry as chalk, with absolutely no moisture as if they had been air dried, and no seasoning. An occasional slice of bell pepper is going to add zilch flavor!

The toast was cold and piled on top of the ham, and this made the ham --by the way, of the Oscar Meyer variety-- seep into the bread. All this for about $7.95, a total gyp since I eventually left much of the food there.

Miss Thang then tried to upbraid me a little later on when I waited possibly 10 minutes for my check. She was doing some clean up, dumping out oil and lard, throwing out garbage and when he finally appeared, I said "Check please", then he shouted "Yes, I heard you!"  He was this close to snapping.

When he got closer I also said "can I get a glass of water", I suppose I forgot to say "please". Geez. Sister girlfriend then yells out to me "S'il vous plait", a curiously fey and mannered response to someone who may or may not know what she is saying. Well it just so happens I do know and I do speak French very well. So I launched into a "Oui, monsieur, s'il vous plait! C'est tres tres gentil". He looked a bit confused as if his bitchiness had been exposed. I can play this game too and still cannot understand why this person decided to be so petulant with me.

So am I expecting much with this dump of a place? At this hour of day? This is a place you probably come to at 4 am after a bender of booze and pills at the clubs across the street. Or you know --you're just about 10 feet away from this new corner on 17th and Castro with the benches where men have deciided to just drop trou (completely)  to the amazement and camera clicks of all tourists.

Save your cash; go somewhere else.
author: Alfonso L.

description: Thier bananna pancakes are so good definetly woth coming just to try those. If you like breakfast then try the 2s two pancakes, 2 sides of bacon sausage and eggs.
author: Anthony M.

description:
My heart...
My soul...
Orphan Andy's.

With All My Love,
Raquel
author: Raquel R.

description:
I've never had a bad meal here, and I've had a few damned good ones. Basic American diner food, good for breakfasts, burgers and similar comfort food.

During the daytime I've always had great service. At night, particularly on weekends, it might be helpful to be a cute guy instead. But I've never had *bad* service.

Also, it's 24 hours and extremely conveniently located for post-movies, post-clubbing or just finding yourself on in the Muni underground with a hankering for some pancakes.
author: Espana S.

description:
Imagine getting a great burger and fries 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year, rain or shine, fair weather or foul.  Orphan Andy's is a grandfatherly welcoming beacon to the Castro, next door to the Twin Peak's bar, often called the glass casket.  Andy's is small in size, enormous in spirit, quality, fun and community history.  Sit at the counter and participate in the creation of your chow, a booth where you can hear sordid stories from drunk or hung over queens suffering endless broken hearts and heels or the coveted window tables where the people watching is as good as it gets with the new mini park and the trolley's loading and off loading all day and most of the night.

Orphan Andy's has survived and thrived through some amazing times in the gateway to the Castro and has always been a symbol of the best qualities of our community and all we do for each other and all of San Francisco, our home of choice.  The bacon cheeseburger here is what a classic American cheeseburger is all about, timeless, delicious and so tasty, add some rings or the fries and you'll exit with a cheek to cheek grin and walk with the gambit of proud gluttony.  Orphan Andy's is an institution and a must visit diner in the Castro and well worth a wait.  I love this place.
author: Stu S.

description: Went back after a long while and I've decided this place is awesome. I got the 2 eggs, 2 bacon, 2 sausage and 2 french toast and it was delicious. I think it was about $10 and the server is incredibly friendly and funny. This is a great place to eat.
author: Carlos A.

description: I have not been here for ages; some things don't change. Thank goodness. First, we had a classic OA experience with political proselyting against the current supervisor ("circumcise the wiener"), nudists and a hyperactive staffer. Oh and note the boy nearby with a huge nose ring. The crowds outside and the streetcar. This is the standard greasy spoon and I almost always get the turkey melt: yum! Good fries. My partner had a good burger. We weren't in it for fancy but as always liked the food and eccentric and eclectic Castro atmosphere. OA is always a must!
author: Richard A.

description: Only giving this place 3 stars because my friends and I (Finally got good service) ...and it was finally not from the (bitchy blond)rude ass server Every time iv been in there he's on his phone being a big C#%T .. seriously i am so surprised he hasn't got fired after reading so many bad reviews about him
author: Adrian G.

description:
the staff is awesome

great pancakes and eggs...filling, lots of butter
author: Cynthia B.

description:
