author: Tricia D.

description: Every time I go its past 2 am and its great. I've never had bad food here and the service is awesome for the middle of the night. you have to get the hot wings if youre into to them.
author: Mike L.

description: I been coming here for over 20 years . I always order a  beacon chesse Burger with fries  . is always good ~! I went last night and the server was so kind and nice to me that I could not help writing this review . I like the decor too it has a  nostalgic gay  Americana dinner feel to it .  well done boys !
author: Liza W.

description: First off, this place is for people watching and late night grubbing only.  It is I think the best choice of this sort of diner in the Castro... it has the best people watching for sure.  And the staff is very nice.
author: Aaron W.

description: Walked in around 5pm on a Thursday. No customers in the place, one server(?) behind the counter. We said hi to him as we walked in and sat down at one of the wet booths. (Apparently the tables had all just been wiped down with a wet cloth.) he ignored us. Not so much as a glance or a "someone will be with you shortly". After about 5 minutes a female server appeared from somewhere in the nether regions of the diner and came to our table with menus. When she came back to take our order, they were out of the cheesecake we had come in for. She brought us ice cream and coffee instead. When it came time to leave, she brought us our check, but never returned to take our payment, so after waiting for awhile, we decided to pay at the register. The guy who had ignored us initially stood there, about 6 feet away from us, stacking plates. Even though he knew we were ready to pay and leave, he continued to stack the plates, ignoring us again. My partner asked him if someone could please take our money. He continued to stack plates. We were getting a little agitated at his complete indifference to us and he finally said " is there a problem?" I said" yes, there's a problem. You seem to think it's more important to stand there and stack plates than take care of customers. We'd like to pay for our food." He told us that our server would be with us in a moment, again, there are no other customers that this guy is helping. He's stacking plates 6 feet away from us, while facing us. I started to tell him what poor service he was giving us as the female server finally appeared again to ring us up. As we left, he followed us out, telling us that we needed to "get some class" and that actually he was on his lunch break. He followed us out of the diner to tell us this, shouting at us as we walked away from him. Perhaps the place was empty for a reason. We won't be going back.
author: Michael W.

description:
I visited Orphan Andy's last Saturday at a pretty late hour.  I've certainly noticed it before but never had a reason to stop in.  The fact that Orphan Andy's is a 24-hour establishment gave me reason.  That's the first good thing about Andy's- I wish all establishments were open 24/7 but most places are simply too inconsiderate.  I ordered the omelettes, and what can I say?  They were good, that's for certain, but then it's pretty hard to screw up omelettes.  Likewise, the toast was satisfactory.  My friend also got breakfast fare and from what I could see it was similarly generic- very good but not difficult to make well.  Continuing this trend of generally well-rounded typcality, the price was reasonable and they didn't skimp on portions.  Just know that is isn't the most spacious of places, the booths holding about four people each

I guess what I'm saying is I haven't tried enough of the menu to give a thorough review but as far as breakfast food goes, it was quite good.  Much better than Denny's, that's for sure.  At least my friend claims to frequent the  place often.  I'm certainly coming back next time I'm out late.

In summary the place was well rounded, but nothing seemed to stand out about it.  Yet it certainly couldn't be called mediochre.  I do believe this place will eclipse Mel's as my late night go to spot.
author: Nicolas M.

description:
Queer, open 24 hours, deverse queerish or friendly folks. good new juke box simular to chances bar in houston, texas which is like the lexington club. 

awsome frys, nice wait staff, coffee is ok, vegan friendly, good frys, and soup, the quavios rancheros is a bit diffrent from texas or cajun style but as good as it gets in the early morning late night, and i am told the hotcakes are good but single fem soft butch transbians need to keep their figure queer and up.


My sponsor turned me on to this place, it doesnt have the drunks like at sparkys, which is why i love diners, they run a tight ship.
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: The service is very friendly(I always tip). The food is wonderful like great home cooking. one of my favorite spots in the basically agree with this. I have only been in to Orphan Any's a few times since I moved here, but each time a pleasant memory. I enjoyed my meal every time and the prices are reasonable. I have not been to much because I don't want to get tired of it, but how is that even possible, m mm good!
author: AJ V.

description:
I came to Orphan Andy's in San Francisco's Castro district about a week ago for breakfast.  It was aesthetically pleasing, with San Francisco history and other pieces of Americana decking the walls with grace and no pretension.  I was there with two friends of mine, and we were waited on by a wonderful gentleman who did not hesitate to call us "loves," "fabulous," and "fantastic" (all comments were greatly appreciated).  His attitude was great, but I felt like the speed of service could have used some adjusting (but maybe this was because we were being metered and had all of forty five minutes from ordering to checking out).  Our primary server was very nice, however there was a rather muscular employee who made no attempt to soften his expression when looking our way (awkward).  

The food came out after what seemed like a short eternity, but a pleasant one.  The furniture, the lighting, and the music overheard led to nice early morning contemplation and conversation which made the time pass smoothly.  The refills on the water and coffee were a little slow, but when they came our server was very charming.  Beware of the half and half, if you're a little drunk or kind of sleepy, you'll fail to see that there is no obvious spout and your coffee and your table may end up with a bit more cream than you'd anticipated as my friend found out five minutes in.  

I thought the food portion was very generous, but despite that, I still felt that things were rather expensive.  I managed to take a close look at three dishes: 1.) The Monte Cristo, which was pretty much a generous helping of breakfast ham lodged between two slices of french toast, complete with a snowcap of powedered sugar served with fries and pickles, 2.) a Hawaiian something or other sandwich that had ham and a piece of grilled Pineapple served with fries, and 3.) The Spanish Omelette with mushrooms, salsa, and two hotcakes.  Nobody finished their entire plate.  I managed to try the Monte Cristo, it was delightfully bad for your health, and the sandwich paired nicely with the tableside jam and I could see myself craving it after a night of drinking.  The omelette left a lot to be desired.  It was a well done omelette by any standards, but it seemed to lack a bit of life.  It tried to compensate for this with a healthy dollop of salsa, but the salsa tasted like I came straight out of mild Pace Picante.  This wasn't bad per se, but it definitely wasn't the "salsa" I had envisioned.  The pancakes were good and large, but they too were pretty standard.  Apparently, the chocolate chip pancakes are to die for, so I think I'll have to go back for those.

In all, it was a decent experience at Orphan Andy's.  I think I'd appreciate the place more if I were out late and wanted something other than Denny's or Lucky Penny.  The service was both good and bad, depending on what you're looking at, so that balanced out into a solid passing grade.  If it were a bit cheaper, I think I could overlook some of the issues I had with the food, but in these times with this economy, I feel like there are other places I'd rather dine.
author: Matthew H.

description: Similar to Bagdad Cafe but no desert fries and less drunk people vomiting outside.
author: Mitsi M.

description: Old school diner delights, great for after a bar crawl or simply after a night out on the town. I had previously visited here nearly 8 years ago, on a similar night, and was glad to finally visit again. The pancakes certainly haven't changed, and that's a good thing--the short stack provides plenty of hearty goodness, with the butter melted nicely over top. And my friend's order of fries came platter size, no apologies there. I'm hoping to make a visit again, as I love the old timey feel and great variety of selections. Our only complaint of the evening was the place was sooo stiflingly warm when we walked in, but fortunately that was remedied soon after by the wait staff's opening of the front door for a breeze. Friendly service that makes you want to come back--glad for this venerable establishment!
author: Ryan T.

description: great 24 hour dinner place to grab some late night breakfast for dinner! nothing fills up a tummy full of booze like some hashbrowns, bacon and french toast!
author: Sophie C.

description:
I've been regular on and off here when in SF.  Daytimes, Michael is queen bee.  Many times I've witnessed his attitude towards other diners and laughed.  I've always been polite and friendly, so I've never had the bad side. Until recently. It seems that it's okay to be friendly and fun, but if you're too friendly and/or too fun, she doesn't like it.  Then the chill comes over, and your table will not be cleared EVER, and when you ask for the check, you wait. And wait.
Michael is one of those queens without a personality, so affects a studied rudeness/loudness to show how interesting she is. Honey, you're the most typical queen in the world, and no amount of 'fabulous' or 'don't burn your mouth parts' will make you interesting. Kindness would work, but you have none.
Another server here was sweet to me until Miss It got in her ear, then it was rude minus 50 years.  Curtis, spread your nice, don't ration it.  And for the love of god, don't turn into Michael. You don't want that life. No one does.
author: Richard H.

description:
After going there this morning, I felt inspired to write a review. It's funny, but I thought I was being too critical - until I started reading others. It seems like Civic Duty to review this place.

The food: greasy diner food. It is what it is. The potatoes are disgustingly greasy. They're actually transparent with grease! The only other time I dined here, my omelet almost slipped off the plate when the waiter set it down because of the brown-yellow pool of sludge it was floating on. Liked my biscuits and gravy, though.

The price: $35.00 for hearty breakfast for two (!!!), with juice and coffee. Not counting tip, but nobody earned one, so that's a moot point. It's cheap diner food that doesn't fit the prices.

The service: I really wish I hadn't supported this place with my business, It wasn't the absolute worst I've had, but I'll certainly put it in my bottom five. I go to a restaurant to eat, not to hear inappropriate catty commentary from the wait staff. Our order came fast enough, coffee was fine. In terms of crowd and such there was no problems for a weekday mid-morning.  I ordered an omelette with potatoes and biscuits/gravy. That was a self-assembled order, so the waiter had to go on about how the menu confuses a lot of customers and must be hard to read. Excuse me? DAMN that waiter needs to shut up, I just told you what I wanted, right? Then what about the other waiter, is it appropriate to walk around eating with food crusted in the corners of his mouth?

I have done my share of service jobs for 20 years, (Yuck, no more) so I understand all to well just how difficult.... Excuse me, just how impossible people can be. The only solution I ever found, was to move on. It is clear that the staff here might want to consider my advice.
author: Tony V.

description: I have been going to Orphan Andy's for over 30 years. I has always been a good experience. Tonight is a different story. Me and my friend sat at the counter and behind the counter was stacked with dirty dishes, napkins, uneaten food, etc.. We ordered our food. It was obvious something was wrong. The waiters were washing the dishes in the sink next to us, My friend began to feel uncomfortable, and decided to leave. He is a man who does not hide his feelings and he sensed something was wrong. He told the waiters he was leaving. I decided to stay. I have a tougher stomach. The meal was served and they placed my friend's meal at his spot on the counter. That was weird since he left. After I finisned eating I  was given the check. I told the waiter I was not paying for my friend's meal (chili cheese fries) He told you he was leaving. He said you came in as a pair so I need to pay or he would call the SFPD. I told him my friend was uncomfortable with the pile of dirty dishes and they way they were washing the plates. He said they were working their asses off. I told him I would pay and it is not you guys fault. I actually felt sorry for the waiters. I left a tip, even though I did not like the situation. I left the restaurant and the waiter followed me and threw my tip at me and said "Don't come back."  So after going to Orphan Andy's for 30 years I guess that is my last time. I told my friend, we should have went for Thai.
author: Andrew B.

description:
This place was honestly my last resort for a sunday morning brunch.  9 am, and though i much preferred to go to either kookiez or Savor on 24th street, the parking is ridiculous there and I was starving.  Since we didn't feel like driving too far, I suggested the Castro.  I used to live right around the corner from the castro on 17th street.  I was about 3 doors down from Orphan Andy's and maybe went there once or twice simply because it was close and cheap.  I had very slow service before, but since I had all morning I decided why not.  The food's not that bad.  So we go, manage to grab the last booth available and the cool guy with the glasses (and adorably gay) comes over to us, greets us very friendly, and asks us if we would like something to drink. I order coffee, and my bf orders orange juice.  It takes about 7 to 8 minutes but we finally get it.  The coffee was disgusting, tasted like heated dishwater but the oj was delicious.  All pulpy, just the way i like it.  Another ten minutes goes by, and he finally comes to take our order.  I get some kind of chili pepper omelette and the bf ordered steak and eggs.  I swear, the food came up in about 10 or 15 minutes, but the server did not bring it around for an additional ten or fifteen.  So by the time we got our food it was lukewarm.  The omelette was ok, chili peppers tasted straight out of a can.  Potatoes were extremely greasy.  The steak made me want to vomit just looking at it.  Greasy, a large amount of fat, and extremely small and thin.  Once cut, it was hardly cooked inside.  But the saving grace of my bf's breakfast were the pancakes.  So fluffy and big, and deliciously buttermilk-y.  
We finished, and waited around for the check for 15 minutes, finally I saw the guy with glasses walk by and I asked him if we were supposed to pay.  In a rather annoyed way, he told me I could do whatever I wanted.  So I stand up front at the register, waiting to pay for at least 5 or 6 minutes, and finally we get out of that greasy joint.
Honestly, much as I love the quaint atmosphere and flamingly gay guy I'm never going back.  Food is not worth the service whatsoever.  And just the queen attitudes you can get there sometimes, is enough to make me lose my appetite.  2 stars only because of the guy with glasses who cheered me up that morning.  Otherwise, highly UNrecommended.
author: Marley E.

description: Ive never had a good experience at this place...being a vegan there are few options for me. the one vegan burger they have is cooked on the same grill as the rest of the meat, and even if you request they cook it i a separate pan or wrap it in aluminum foil before grilling it, they always refuse. The staff is very rude and unhelpful....sparkys is DEFINITELY MUCH better!!!
author: John G.

description: Orphan Andy's is a great little find.  Open 24hours! The service is excellent, the food is fresh and tasty... its as good as diner food gets.  I'll be back again =)
author: Paula Y.

description:
my first stop in san fran after arriving 3 hrs late from an abysmal united flight. 24 hr diner, here i come. i was hungry and andy gave me bacon. when i asked for my bacon burnt, andy didn't scoff, he gave it to me just the way i like it. bacon makes everything better.

yeah, so, my blt on sourdough was delicious. my coffee was fresh, the cream on the table... not so much. the service was prompt and all, just not particularily friendly.
author: Rachel P.

description: Hell Yeah! These guys are the greatest 24/7. Have the cream cheese burger. You'll never get over it.
author: Tash T.

description: I agree with the other reviews that say that the food sucks.  It's as if almost all of the food was purchased in a bag or box at the grocery store and reheated.  The salad was nasty too.  The people are nice, but the quality of the food was so bad I wouldn't even go there if I were drunk.
author: Tim T.

description: We came here for gay breakfast on a sunny San Francisco morning. When I stepped in, I immediately noticed the gay butterflies hanging from the ceiling, and the many kinds of gay persons eating here. Our gay waiter gave us a table right away, called us his darlings, and sat down and discussed his day with us. I had a craving for hash browns, which turned out to be the only thing that was not on the menu. I decided on the "Big 2" instead, which came with gay pancakes and gay little sausages and eggs. The pancakes were engineered by the clever gay cook to soak up all the butter and maple syrup I could pour on them. Everything was delicious and inexpensive!
author: Daniel E.

description: I love the Castro and I want to love Orphan Andy's, but every time I've gone there the food has disappointed. And diner food is one of the easiest things to please me with! Bland and overpriced for what you get. I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Katie S.

description: Great atmosphere and friendly wait staff.  My favorite is the crispy onion rings; however, the french fries were not so crispy and were a disappointment.
author: Dale R.

description:
excellent greasy spoon fare. went to OA on the first day of the new year for a very early breakfast. i had the pancake combo plate. as stated in an earlier review, the pancakes are delicious. they are also huge. i couldn't finish them. 

service was excellent considering how packed the place was. the ambiance was great and i loved that janet jackson's early hits were bumpin' on the jukebox. 

if you want simple diner fare at a reasonable price, this is a great place to check out.
author: dorena b.

description: Our waiter here was awesome. He was very sarcastic and didn't take shit from the other people in there. The food was fine, and priced average. It's open 24 hours, so that's a star in itself.
author: Tim M.

description: Its a great tiny hole in the wall place! The service is friendly, the food is good and the portions are very big! One of my favorite spots to have a late night breakfast! Who needs IHOP when you can come to Orphan Andy's for real food! I would have given it 5 stars but i hate waiting to get in!
author: Lucky M.

description: Open 24 hours! the food is better than most 24 hour places! It's much better than Sparky's, and I'd give café mason one star next to this one!
author: Maddy S.

description: Small resaurant with standard fare, good prices and fun/funny staff. Definitely great for breakfast. If in the area give it a try. I really enjoyed it.
author: Jerry D.

description: Although my mother told me that I have always had a sophisticated palette, I should be exempt for this review since I was drunk off my keister. I usually prefer a big, hot bowl of ramen after a night of drinking, but since there was a 24-hour-diner right at my fingertips, a cheeseburger with fries sufficed. I surprisingly didn't throw up after imbibing three shots of tequila and a beer before hand. That has to say SOMETHING for diner food. Put another dime in the jukebox, baby.
author: I Love Beef C.

description: I don't suggest going here at night, when the party boys and girls of the Castro come in and compete cattily for seats.  However, if you can make it here for lunch or breakfast, sit at the counter and perk up your ears... if you're eating alone, you soon will find the most interesting conversations going on between the staff and the regulars at the counter, and you soon might find yourself joining in or at least hear some really interesting stories.  You'll instantly feel steeped in thirty years' worth of San Francisco gay culture right at perhaps the most queer crossroads in the United States.  I recommend the Big 2 with French Toast.
author: Chris B.

description: I am from Woodbury, mn, and I admit I only went there because my daughter Misty used to work there. But once there, I enjoyed the food immensely. The atmosphere was very friendly. The food was amazing, I intend to go back every time I come to San Francisco. Good job!
author: Laurie W.

description: When The Club closes at 2am and you need to eat something while you wait for your booty call to get done partying it up at Ruby Skye until 4am, you should come here.  Which is what I did.  With my best friend who is a tranny (which should pretty much be a prerequisite).  We waited in line for a while but didn't feel rushed when we ordered and ate so I can't complain.  My eggs, pancakes and ham were decent and at 3am I'm not really going to complain.  Huge portions too for very little. Would I come here in the light of proper day? Certainly not.  It was good for the occasion though and since Nizario's closed down like punk bitches before I could get a slice.
author: Jill D.

description: Great diner food.  Also good service with really friendly wait-staff.
author: Dan P.

description: Last year we went here because we could not find anything else open at 4 am to eat. My buddy and me who are both straight came here and everything was fine. The waiter was cool and everything was good. Their burgers are good and my friend's eggs looked pretty good. So we paid our bill and all of a sudden this drunk guy starts yelling at my friend about how he wants to take his belt off and starts yelling "HEY BLONDIE". It was an interesting experience but I don't plan on coming here again for personal reasons. Good food though.
author: Darius A.

description: gotta love the cute boys in there and the good food :P
author: Anthony J.

description: Suitably scary as a 24-hour old-school Castro diner. This may have been the last restaurant flaunting the smoking bad in California. But if greasy-spoon is what you want, it is probably better than the others in proximity. Anybody remember Church St. Station? Now *that* was classic scary Castro.
author: patrick g.

description: It's a diner, the staff is interesting (although not what you would call amiable) and the biscuits and eggs come out right.  And when you are nearly dead from your previous night's behavior, that's all that matters, no?  There are better breakfast places in the morning, but not that many at 3 or 4am so close to the trough you are stumbling out of.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Gotta love Orphan Andy's.  It's oh-so 70s and that is oh so comforting.  This place has been there forever and the food is always good and the same.  It's my place to go when I am really wasted or hungover and need french fries and pancakes.  One needs that combo in a certain states and the folks at Andy's know that and embrace it.
author: Sean O.

description: Very good food in a cool part of SF. I had the Philly Cheesesteak, Which was pretty good, though I probably should have had something else. The milkshakes, however, are great and the food is very good.
author: Zach H.

description: To tell the truth, it is not my type of food.  Which is to say, I don't really like diner food.  That being said, I made it a Friday habit to walk up there from 21st and Mission, where I have my therapy session, to eat.  "Why?" you may ask yourself.  Well, the two pretty boy (gay) waiters there flirt shamelessly with me, even though I wear women's clothes...and everybody knows gay guys don't like tranz people.  I wish I could remember their names.  Now that it is chillified outside - that is to say, summer has left us - I don't make the trek.  I will go back when the crazy cold snaps and it gets toasty again.  Hope they are still around.  One of them, the younger one, came up to me at the Folsom Street Fair, and tackled me with a hug.  I couldn't remember how I knew him, because he was out of context.  Anyway, that is my Orphan Andy review.  Thank you, and good bye.
author: M. J.

description: Breakfast is cooked to order 24 hours a day.  Service is fast and if you can get the window booths a great view of the local scene. Convenient to public transportation.
author: Lincoln G.

description: To top off an already exceedingly awkward evening...our waiter dropped a stack of dirty dishes on me as he was busing our table.  No thanks.
author: Ky W.

description:
It is 1:30 am and boyfriend and I have the munchies.   I know that I have no business eating at 1:30 am- I've been working out, I've been eating right and my body is my priority.  I should just go home and go to bed.  Boyfriend suggests that maybe I don't have to be perfect all of the time (or something to that effect).  
Sold. 
We walk in and there are many healthy  and lean - looking men enjoying stacks of pancakes and fries and burgers and "naughty food".    I notice that I am the only woman in the place.   Although there may have been someone who was a woman at one time or another in their life.  I give up trying to tell.  Who cares?  That's why we live in SF, right?
We decide, for the sake of caloric restriction and in the spirit of moderation, to enjoy a shared tuna melt and fries.  
We order a tuna melt and fries to share and giggle and forget what we were saying halfway through the sentence and continue to laugh at incomplete thoughts.  
The food was perfect and by that, I mean that it was straightforward diner food, served promptly (by the guy with the glasses who was fascinating looking) and I was left wishing for nothing. Meanwhile, the bars had closed and, without any rushing or prodding from our waiter, we relinquished our table. 
 
Two days later, when BF and I were in the neighborhood after a show, I had to ask him, coyly, "hey baby, are you hungry?" hoping he'd suggest another tuna melt...
author: Maria C.

description: It's open 24 hours.  It's in San Francisco.  I don't even care about the food (it's not bad) -- 5 stars.
author: Danny C.

description:
Pay special attention to whether the reviewer is male or female regarding this place. I went here because I am still trying to find a local, walkable, greasy spoon to replace Herb's and, geez, I knew there was a reason why I never came here in the 12 years I've lived in this city.

First off, I went in at 11 am on a weekday- breakfast time.  Perfect time to see how a restaurant really is without the excuses of it being busy or late-in-the-day-therefore-no-specials-and-I'm-tired-and-cranky, said the waitstaff in a huffy tone.

There were 3 guys. Two gay dudes up front and a Latino guy doing all the grunt work in the back. I sit down. No eye contact. Silly me for wearing my I-AM-A-LESBIAN button today. I order and everything's fine so far (except for the button wearing.) I got coffee but I'm a pussy and I need milk. I ask for it. And Younger Dude says, "it's right there in front of you" and pointed like a librarian in a foul mood.  I had to tell him, "really, it's not here." So, YD does that rolling eye, exhaling thing that gay guys do! Hmph! Well, he comes around and sees that it is indeed not there. So he fills up another creamer to the brim and puts it in front of me.  It was so full that it spilled when I poured it. He didn't even try to help me. Thanks. A. Lot.

The phone rings. Older Dude answers it and talks at length and finally turns around to the Latino Dude and yells, "I'M TRYING TO HEAR THE PHONE, STOP BANGING AROUND IN THERE! GEE. SUS!" Now, poor LD (whose name, I am certain, is not Jesus) was only cooking and cleaning and stocking and shelving and wasn't paying attention to OD.  AND never mind that the jukebox was blaring Diana Ross. Geez., get a grip.

Well, on to the food. It was fine. Nothing special. I won't come back here again unless I am glamed up pretending to be a man that is pretending to be a woman.  Yep. Try to figure that one out.

p.s. still looking for corned beef hash in a can without having to make it myself. if it's out there, come find me.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Ahhh Orphan Andy's. The Castro mainstay. After drinking the night away for a friend's birthday, what's better than getting eggs over-easy with a side of sausage ;)? This is the place to go if you're craving breakfast at any time of day in the Castro. Cool staff and yummy food - what else can you ask for?
author: Danny L.

description: Horrible, horrible horrible! I'm from then neighborhood and I went there a few times and the food was blah. The last two times I went with my partner and the bearded guy with the Scottish skirt had such an uptight attitude we did not enjoy our McDonalds dinner and the second time he was so rude we dropped our menus and left. Come to find out 9 out of my 10 friends had an awful experience with this restaurant. I believe in giving a place a second chance, but this place is beyond repair, I'm very sorry to say. STAY AWAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: M F.

description:
I'm in love with a sandwich and I'm ok with that.

Whenever I need comfort food or just food, the Monte Cristo never disappoints.  Though I miss their old fries, the ones with the skins on them, bring those back please.

Love, Cupcake
author: BH ..

description: For whatever reason we managed to get a seat immediately on a Saturday night... perhaps we were so drunk that we inadvertently cut in line? Not sure. Either way... this is a totally gay, kickass 70s style diner. My meatball sub owned, and the vegetable soup was great. Both of my friends loved their breakfasty foods. The service was very fast, and the food wasn't that expensive. Also it was great people watching, and the brutally catty exchanges were hilarious.
author: Evan K.

description:
I really want to like this place.  I've tried it a couple of times and it's always a disappointment.  Most recently, the meatloaf was absolutely horrid.  I couldn't eat it (and strongly encourage everyone to avoid it if you eat here).

I love that it's open 24/7 and in the Castro.  But that's about it.
author: Maverick M.

description:
had the tuna melt on rye with some fries. it was good. nothing special....

a friend of mine had an episode outside when he couldn't handle his alcohol at 11pm. this was the nearest solution we came to, to suppress that.
author: Paul A.

description: One of my favorite restaurants to go for breakfast in SF. Servers are always super nice and food is always fresh! I Looove It!
author: Kenny B.

description: Great fries (with skins!) and milkshakes (super thick!) - the rest of the food is meh, but the theater of the place and the Donna Summer selections on the jukexbox make it my back-up diner of choice.
author: Angela C.

description: Pricey, but good portions and yummy food. This place is good for a low-key meal, with $$$ cost.
author: Al N.

description: My friend and I went here last night at around 11pm.  It is a cute little diner with a friendly staff.  We sat in a cozy booth where we listened to music from those 25 cent jukeboxes at our table.  Since it was cold, I decided on a cup of minestrone soup.  It came pretty fast and it was good--great amount of vegetables.  My friend got a veggie burger with onion rings. She said it was good and the onion rings weren't greasy at all.  Definitely low-key and the people and food is great!
author: Mel P.

description: Walking in to this place, I'm hopeful since it has a diner vibe, and growing up in NJ, I feel I've got a good handle on diners.  Service was very friendly.  veerrrry friendly.  Toooo friendly?  The coffee was really weak.  Did they do anything other than glance at the coffee grinds while they poured warm brown liquid into my cup?  Chili omelette was forgettable.  Food took quite sometime to arrive, not very diner like.  Meh.
author: Parker W.

description: This is a great "old school" diner.  One of the few left in San Francisco.  The menu is expansive and high quality at the same time.  And the atmosphere is mellow  and friendly, like an old counter style diner.  If you are looking for tasty, cheap, and fun, while hanging out in the castro, I highly recommend Orphan Andy's
author: Russell S.

description: Good food. Great for post drinking. Def not high quality or healthy but tasty and filling after/during a night of drinking.
author: Art A.

description: I have two words: "banana pancakes". It's like the bananas are caramelized or something. They're so good! I had banana pancakes at the Cove the other day and they were downright pathetic compared to Orphan Andy's. The waiters are consistently warm and witty and there's always an interesting mix of folks in there, including a smattering of folks who have been up for days.
author: James W.

description: Ok, this is not the place to come for the health conscious but if you want a quaint, friendly 24hour diner in the Castro this is it!  On the weekends, it's hard to get in, but thru the weekday it doesn't get as packed. This place has obviously been around for a long time and the dining area has that nostalgic feel. The food, eh, pretty average..
author: C R.

description:
Oh thank goodness, I have found the perfect late night cheap meal. 
Eggs over easy- perfect.
Hamburger patty -very good
Potatoes -  very good
Toast- average, but not burnt
Spite - too sweet
Service - a little slow, but only two waiters and ours at least 
                 got us the food hot and was apologetic and rushed.
                  Dude, who we paid our bill to was such a snob, My
                  message to you, "Better to be a peasant than to be
                 one who servs peasants" 
Overall - Food was Great and will be back for more.
author: Jaye L.

description: Great food and an outstanding staff. I've eaten here for years and it feels like family. It's amazing what can be done in a fairly small space.I love it.
author: Michael B.

description:
I loved reading these reviews of Orphan Andy's -- it's like reading a novel about the living, breathing history of the Castro. 

Had breakfast there on Friday: good bacon, OK eggs, wretched pancakes (like Play-Doh).

But it was all fine, because my waiter was beautiful, oblivious Matthew (in-and-out English accent, glasses, v-shaped torso, tight t-shirt, great butt) who called me "luv," and was extra nice.
author: Joe B.

description: Unlike other reviews, our server was great.  The food was A-OK, nothing fantastic, nothing too amazing.  It was a busy night, and the whole joint just felt a bit greasy.  But it's a diner, so i guess greasy is in order.  I could take it or leave it.
author: Todd C.

description:
Grease Bomb!  I always find myself at this hole in the wall after binge drinking in the Castro.  If there's a line here fuggetaboutit! Don't wait, It's not all that.  Go get yourself a slice of pizza down the block. 

 I used to take my friends from out of town here, 
1.) cause it was the only thing open after hours 
2.) it wasn't Denny's 
3.) I was stoned and with an extreme case of the munchies. 

 I used to love it here just for the entertainment and influx of people watching, that is until some drag queen threw a tomato at me from across the room (she was a big Ms. Thang skurrry girl too).  
My last memory of this place was Exxon Valdez rain-bowed grease swirls atop my Pepsi glass, and pancakes that had an ice cream scoop sized portion of margarine sitting on top of them.  My first inclination was to retaliate and fling this monster portion of margarine back toward the drag queen that threw a tomato in my direction.  But then I thought no (me being a weeee lil person) wouldn't want to get beat down in the streets by some big black Wesley Snipes looking drag queen.
Mildly health conscious? This is not the place for you.  You'll gain weight from the grease fumes alone. The restroom might as well be an out house(it's the same size only dirtier with a tiny wash basin)  A classic (not classy) San Franciscan greasy spoon, 50's decor but reeks of 70's nostalgia.
author: B H.

description: NOTE: i am only rating this place for one thing only.. their turkey burger is the BEST turkey burger i have ever had in my life! it GO! mMm hMMmm!
author: jennifer c.

description: Probably my favorite 24 hour spot in the city. Good food at any time of the day -- what more can you ask for?! I usually end up getting a burger, but you can order breakfast at any time of the day. It's small and cozy enough to ensure that you're never overlooked, and fellow patrons are usually quite cheerful.
author: Jon M.

description: Great place to go to late night after bar hopping, clubbing or whatever it is you do after midnight during the wee hours of the early morn! Be warned it is a total dive but it serves it's purpose and it's patrons well. My favorite is to have breakfast items like eggs and bacon and greasy home fries. Yummers!!! It's all good people! Give them a try. I think you'll like it.
author: Yolee R.

description: I had hesitated on going here because several of my friends said it was no good.  Well, I was early for work one day & so I decided to stop for breakfast. (I go to Castro Street Station, so I was right there).  Well, I liked it.  AND...I discovered that it is open 24 hours.  So, the next time I get wasted & consequently ravenous, I have a guaranteed place to go.
author: Charlene E.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. It is probably my favorite diner in the City, thanks to the wonderfully funny servers, tasty comfort food (the tuna melts, and veggie burgers are my favorite), and cozy atmosphere. They always remember my face (if not my name), and know what I'd like to drink. Even on a busy night, the friendly servers will make a pit stop at our booth to say hello.
author: jessica f.

description:
I wish we could give "zero" stars! I started going to OA when it opened and have had many enjoyable encounters with the food and staff. Today marked the last time I will ever set foot in this sad sad joint. Sat down around 2:00 pm and had to wait some time to give our order - that's not a biggy. Our youngish waiter finally took the time to take our order. Two tables were seated after us - they were served their food and were eating. Our food -who knows where it was. We had to re-feed the meter. The food arrived. I ordered the hamburger steak medium rare - made a point of saying that twice, with two eggs over easy. I cannot believe how over cooked the hamburger was, inedible. I guess that is what took so long for our food to arrive -that alone would have take twenty minutes. The home fries actually had blackened burnt parts. The eggs were cooked over easy -really over easy the eggs were basically raw. The toast was soggy, I am hoping that was from way too much butter, My partners food had obviously sat under a heat lamp while my burger was being burnt.
When I told the waiter I would pay for the two eggs and toast but not the rest he was obliging and took my entire breakfast off the check. However it would have been better to offer to have my breakfast remade ... oh well. It does make me sad that this destination is off my Castro map of restaurants.
author: Sam L.

description: I was in town only for one week, but I think we ate here three times!  The southwestern omlette was so delicious and the rootbeer float was really good too.  Late night hours are really convenient for those late night cravings.  The staff were a little stuffy, but overall pretty fun once you poked them a few times.  Oh and I can not forget to mention the banana pancakes - WOW!
author: Charlie S.

description:
I cannot lie. I love this place. I love it too much.
One of my favorite things is to eat here and then catch a movie over at the Castro theater.
They are always open, have HUGE portions, and the food is soooo good. AND CHEAP. Which totally floats my boat, being an impoverished student.
Okay, so it's diner food, but you know what? I've had bad diner food. And this place makes amazing grilled cheese sandwiches and CHOCOLATE CHIP BANANA PANCAKES!
The service is always amazing, I am never wanting for refills at all.
My first experience here, was me at the bar at nearly midnight, and the service was JUST as AWESOME then as during the day, even though I just a tea and some fries.
As far as little hole in the wall places go, this is one of my absolute favorites. If you haven't gone here, shame on you, go now, no really, just get up and go now. You won't be sorry.
Parking in Castro is pretty much always harry, but it's literally RIGHT across the street from the muni station.
author: Lin B.

description: I love the fact that it's 24 hours, great location not to mention the friendly staff!!!
author: Anthony J.

description: I don't think I'd choose to eat here sober.  But, drunk at 2-something in the morning. . . .hell yea!h  I'ts hard to do bacon and eggs wrong and I'm too drunk to notice anyway.  I do remember from my trip there last night that the pancakes were really damn good.
author: Jeff P.

description: Delicious banana pancakes for dinner. Not too expensive. Definitely would recommend for anyone who loves breakfast food. It's like an awesome
author: Nelson C.

description:
THE BAD NEWS:  Vegans will starve here and there are few options for vegetarians.  Inflexible seating means groups of more than 4 will be split up (unless you can crowd into a booth designed for 4 average-sized people).  At busy times (weekend breakfast and late night) you will be asked to wait outside until you can be seated (cold?  rainy?  we're so sorry, but we do have an awning).  These are also the times when errors are sometimes made by the one frazzled cook in the tiny kitchen.  The single-person unisex restroom is located through the kitchen, down the stairs (past the dragon and don't wake up the troll if you know what's good for you).  Obnoxious twits who wander in at peak times with a sense of VIP entitlement and a bad attitude will meet a waitstaff who have been there, done that, and won't hesitate to give as good as they get.  Distressed vegans will be reminded that the menu was posted at the door.

THE GOOD NEWS:  Patient omnivores who come to Orphan Andy's alone or with one or three friends are in for good, solid comfort food with a few very special highlights.

I think the housemade chicken vegetable soup is one of the best kept secrets in SF.  Maybe not haute cuisine, but Mama wishes she could make it like this.  Big chunks of meat and lots of veggies.  You can choose it instead of fries with your sandwich or burger.  Or the (also housemade) minestrone.

Orphan Andy's is one of the few places I've seen a Monte Cristo sandwich in SF.  It's like ham and swiss cheese on french toast.  Spread it with jam or pour on some syrup.

The space is "intimate," and at the counter, people sometimes strike up conversations.  If you came in by yourself, you might make a new friend.

If you can accept Orphan Andy's limitations, it's a great diner to dine in.

DISCLAIMER:  I'm not and have never been employed at Orphan Andy's, nor do I have an interest in the business.  But I've been a regular there for decades and have become friends with some of the waitstaff and the owner.
author: Charlie G.

description: Im not sure what all these reviewers expect from an all night diner..but orphan andys is the perfect greasy spoon...they have amazing..really amazing-pancakes..and anything else ive ordered has been fine...its a great place to meet a friend, have a burger, listen to the jukebox, and be on your way...the staff has always been nice and if you want something fancy, go somewhere fancy with all the other food snobs.
author: lesley s.

description: Sexy boys and by far the BEST country gray in the city. Mmmmm soooooo good.  Huge stacks of pancakes, biscuits and gravy, and chicken fried steak are amazing.  Words can't even describe the fact that Orphan Andy's is unparalleled.
author: Kris J.

description: Totallty, come here if you want food poisoning from under prepared meat and rude service! For sure
author: Jamie C.

description:
My girlfriend and I both felt sick after eating here.

Little bit of a wait on a Saturday morning, which is to be expected.  We sat at the counter and it took forever for the waiter at the counter to take our order and way way way too long for our food to come, especially for the quality.

The food is ok, not great.  I've eaten a lot of greasy spoon and this place isn't all that great.  I think the food is too expensive for the quality, but maybe that's just San Francisco pricing.  I probably would have given this place another try if it weren't for the fact that we both felt really ill for a few hours after eating there.

The best part of this place is the atmosphere and the waiters who were very friendly.
author: S S.

description: Had a late lunch at OA's last week. Been going there at off hours for years. The food was acceptable as always, but the floor show was really the attraction that day. I have never seen someone so tweaked out of their mind, who was not in a cheap motel room with all the bed coverings draped over the window. The waiter was literally bouncing around the place at warp speed. He came over to the dirty unwiped down counter (the whole counter was sticky with the days spills) to take my order, but then threw the order pad down on the counter and went rushing out on the sidewalk to socialize with some people he knew? As I was just left sitting there I noticed that there were piles of dirty dishes on the other side of the counter, about to fall off on the floor. He came back in and bounced off the walls a bit more, before he finally came back to the pad, to take the order. I thought he was gong to chew his lips off as he wrote down the order, but luckily they stayed attached. Anyway got what I wanted and was just careful not to touch the dirty counter.
author: Kevin S.

description: I hadn't eaten here since I moved to S.F. in 95. I now remember why Andy is an Orphan.... the food killed his parents.
author: santiago g.

description: Orphan Andy's is a particular type of San Francisco business.  Their food ranges from perfectly acceptable to pretty good, but this place is all about CHARACTER.  The character of the place (greasy spoon by way of a European independent film festival) waiters (mostly gay, mostly sweet and catty by turns) and the character of the clientele (late night - mostly drunk, occasionally obnoxious, always an adventure).  This place is not for the faint of heart, but that is why I like it.
author: Jude F.

description:
Im not too fond of the diner setting. I find that most diners tend to lack good service and push the rushed service.
I happend upon Orphan Andys on a saturday night. My friends and I had been out drinking and decided to get some food at this castro establishment. There was about four people total in my party. The crowd was so large that they told us to wait outside in the rain for a table. This seemed a little strange to me but it was a small diner and I assumed this was normal. We were getting take out so I didnt understand why we couldnt wait inside. After a half hour passed, our food was ready. I wasnt impressed with any of it to be honest. The fries were cold and tasted like they had been out for quite some time. The turkey burger was nothing impressive. It cost about $25.00 for two of us to eat and we thought the food was terrible. I understand that a diner is not going to be culinary cuisine but come on! It was a turkey burger and bacon burger...how hard is it o mess it up?  I assume the poor food was due to lack of service and too many customers. I think I will steer clear of this diner in the future and find somewhere else to spend my money.
author: Adam B.

description: My dad and I ate here after we walked around the city for like 6 hours and worked up one hell of an appetite. I got the tuna melt which was really good. The potato salad was not good though. I ended up eating half of my dad's fries. My dad did mention that he barely fit in the bathroom and he is in really great shape. This is definitely a diner, I think you'd have to be blind not to notice this. Diner's serve up greasy, non healthy food. This is not Gary Danko but sometimes you're just in the mood for a greasy tuna melt! Big portions and easy on the wallet.
author: Pamela M.

description:
My husband first took me here back in the spring. He loves the food and I agree it was a good breakfast in such a tiny hole-in-the-wall atmosphere.
The guy who seemed to be in charge was quite courteous and friendly. He immediately greeted us and sat us as soon as a table was ready. The food came out quick and hot.
Now for the 2 star review rating...
We came back on New Years Day when we spent New Years Eve in SF.
We brought a friend, his older daughter and her boyfriend.
We walk in and all of the tables and the bar was full, but we were the only ones waiting. It also looked like each person had JUST gotten served so it looked like we were in for a wait. Not only did we NOT get a greeting or an acknowledgement, I was given a rude request...to move so he can get by. I smiled, apologized in the sweetest way and moved over, to which he returned with a sour look on his face.Our friend's daughter was told to "wait outside". I promptly went outside and called my favorite breakfast establishment in the Haight..."All You Knead". We all filed out of that rude new years experience and headed for what turned out to be a GREAT new years experience!
I MIGHT give them another chance, but come on! I have to be desperate to cram myself into such a small place just for some breakfast food I can enjoy someplace else.
HAPPY NEW YEAR!
author: Lisa S.

description: OMG!!!!! I love this place! My friend took me here the other night after the club. Its 24 hours, we got a seat rite away, and service was fast and very friendly! We had the cheese fries and onion rings they were the bomb! I'm in love with the onion rings here dip them in ranch now that's perfection!
author: Mary S.

description: I'm not sure what most of these "nitwit" reviewers expect from an all-night diner in the Castro...if you want service and great lighting...go to Fleur de Lys...but i'm betting you cant get the best fried chicken and chicken fried steak this side of the south. You can at Andy's!
author: Susan L.

description: This review is based solely on the onion rings.  They might be the best I have ever had. And let me tell you I am an expert.   Ask for some triple dip action.   Ketchup, BBQ, and ranch.  I might die young after eating these but worth every bite.
author: kristine m.

description: Good old-fashioned diner food at reasonable prices!
author: Alan G.

description:
Late at night, and you want a real meal, not just a quick slice of pizza?

Dining alone between happy hour and your late night cruising?

Want real food that actually tastes good and quick, friendly service?

Andy's does it all, consistently.  Diner fare whipped up by a very quick short-order cook.  Great soup.  Best iced tea for miles around.   Friendly (and if you're lucky, even flirty!) waiters.  There's a reason why there's often a line out the door.  

Great value for money, too.  I can't cook at home this cheap.
author: Dean A.

description: Sometimes the service isn't that great but that's not why you come here is it? I know for sure I am never there for the service but the great open atmosphere this place has! Not to mention its always open! I suggest breakfast! Shana says she loves the stuffed french toast (she wanted her two cents in)
author: Daniel L.

description:
it was late, we were hungry, Orphan Andy's was open

good malts and grilled cheese w/ fries! lots of breakfast items to choose from so you wont get bored
author: Bianka G.

description: So good!  Best biscuits and gravy in the city.  Like mom made back home.  The service is not great unless they know you, and the prices are a little high for the fare.  And that's all if you can get in.
author: Monika M.

description: My favorite diner in the city. It's greasy and delicious, just like it should be. When you order fries, they bring you out a full plate of fries. Unlike Sparky's, who give this little miniature bowl of fries. Try to make it there before 2:00am or you're going to have a long wait.
author: Paul W.

description: I'd have to say, the food is okay. The food is really not that great. The portions are not that great. The service is not that great. I didn't try out the washroom, but I'm sure, it's not that great. What is great, well, nothing really. The place is open late (24 hour), but that's the only perk. That's why it gets two stars. The diner is a little cramped, but that's not a big deal. The place feels like Mel's. The difference is that Mel's feels like they're trying harder. This place needs to take a page out of Mel's book and try to spruce things up a bit more.
author: Andrew Y.

description: It's really about three and a half, but I'll round up for the gay (no pun intended) atmosphere. The mood can change drastically according to the waitperson on duty, but it is usually pretty entertaining and the food is okay. Great location, been there for years, and open 24 hours. I had been hung-up on Bagdad and neglected Andy's for years, but the boys down the street are getting a bit pretentious so I came back. I'd mostly stick to the breakfast and hamburgers, but like I said it is great entertainment day or night.
author: Robert M.

description: We stumbled into Orphan Andy's after having a few drinks at the bar, as I'm sure most customers here do. I ordered the spinach omelet, which wasn't bad for a 24 hour dinner. The home fries were ok. My friend seemed to really enjoy her hot cakes. Prices are pretty steep, something I didn't quite understand. I was considering a grilled cheese but it was $7!!! It's just bread, butter and cheese! I don't understand their pricing. Place is small and can get pretty crowded late at night.
author: Cori W.

description: I was expecting the typical "Denny's-type atmosphere." To my surprise, we were greeted by an adorable gay-boy who served up delicious coffee, cake, pie, fries. . . and all the other fatty foods you want at 2AM. Granted, it's no find cuisine, but seriously. It's awesome. All the Tom Jones my heart desires!
author: Liz L.

description: I came here on March 9th at 2 am in the morning. Not the best country gravy. Service was good, especially considering the fact that they were dealing with a drunk picky me. I liked it better than Sparky's.
author: Lorraine B.

description: Kind of a greasy diner, but meatloaf to die for, and open late!!!  The staff are very friendly, and  the other customers at the bar tend to be talkative. 3.5 stars.
author: Meredith G.

description: It's open 24 hours -- which is good to know in this city.  But, the breakfast was average, and the o.j. was the worst o.j. i have ever seen or attempted to drink -- frozen chunks of pulp.  grody.
author: Tim G.

description: My husband and I are hungry, live right down the block, and this spot is the only one open @ 2am on a Monday night...Atmosphere was good, food was decent yet overpriced (shocker). Our "waiter"???? THE WORST EVER. I mean, he was MEAN, bitter, pouty, and I'm not sure if he lost his voice or just was unable to speak. Despicable, as mother used to say. Ruined our experience, to the point that we will never return.  And we would've been regulars. Hated it, thanks to Mr. Personality
author: Laura Noël S.

description: Went here last night with my stepdad, & the food was good, except for the home fries (I'm a potato fan, & this is what made it 4 instead of 5 stars). The staff was very nice, & it's totally awesome that it's open 24 hours! They also have awesome dessert: the double chocolate fudge cake is screamin!
author: Caroline B.

description: Ok, so this was my second time in here because I wanted to give them another try to see if they could improve.   I guess I was wrong.  From the hot, disinterested server that had his arms crossed the whole time, to the old geezer who couldn't spend less than 30 seconds to refill my soda, this place is a no-go.    Fries soggy, our toast the first time around was moist, toast~ not a sponge.   Anyway, too bad, they were close and the young man behind the counter is hot, but not interested in his job, and it shows.  Can I give .5 stars?
author: a b.

description: This place is sweet in all the best and worst ways. Tiny, cute space, welcoming staff. My extra malt chocolate malt had a whole lot of chocolate syrup. The pulled pork bbq sauce was a sugar bomb. Even the thousand Island dressing on my reuben was like candy. Need sugar? You'll love it here. Food was salty, greasy, sweet. The onion rings were really good.
author: J. R.

description:
UPDATE (05/28/08): so maybe two's a charm? i originally gave this place 4-stars after only one visit. perhaps a little pre-mature? possibly. my second visit gave me reason to not really like this place. the food was not as good and the service was piss poor. ok, so there could be a combination of reasons why my second visit was not as good: could be because i ordered breakfast - instead of the veggie burger i ordered the first time? the veggie burger and fries was good! but this second time i decided to try their breakfast - most notably their supposedly famous pancakes! well, their breakfast was just a grease puddle and their pancakes were spongy and had about two sticks of lard on top of the pancakes. notes to self, IF and if i go back here, i shall ask for butter on the side. so overall, not a great experience the second time around. no reason to really go back to this place. perhaps the only reason is because they're open 24 hours. however, that's pretty useless for me since i rarely do the whole drinking until 2am and then going for a sparkies run anymore. so i give edit my rating and give this place 3-stars, which means, it's not great but it's not bad. it is what it is.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: 4-stars? perhaps a little too high? i've only been here one time (a few days ago), but my experience was very good. good comfort food at reasonable prices. very good and super friendly service. waiters were oozing with sarcasm and wit. i've lived in the hood for about 6 months and have always avoided trying this place. i'm glad i tried it because now it's definately a weekend breakfast option for me.
author: James J.

description: Hooray for old school Castro joints like Orphan Andy's!  There are so few of them left... you know... before the rainbow explosion and the influx of evil chains!  Yeah, anyway... burgers!  Delicious. (Okay I don't eat meat anymore, but I have friends who do and they tell me that they are delicious here.)  And the late night breakfasts... well, if I'm eating pancakes at 1:30am at Orphan Andy's, I know I'm having a good time.
author: Lisa W.

description: Zachary behind the counter is an awesome dude (the only straight dude in the Castro!) and he hooked it up with the Root Beer Float...I didn't have food here yet, but I will be back on one of my late night excursions for chicken fried steak at 3 am! The vibe here is awesome, it feels like coming to a friend's house for snacks and good conversation...definitely visit this place...
author: Ronaldo T.

description: What can I say.... this place is open 24 hours. You will find greasy burgers, breakfast at anytime of the day, and cheery servers. Orphan Andy's is representative of the community and the neighborhood. For better service, sit at the bar; you will get prompt service and attention. This is also a good place to get over a hangover or a burger fix.
author: Phillip T.

description: Best little diner around. It's open 24 hours but I go there for lunch. The food is standard diner fare but it's tasty. I mostly go there with my friend Nick, just to hear him say how much one of the servers looks like Tobey Maguire in Spider-Man.
author: Leah C.

description:
orphan andy's over sparky's, any day. i love both joints but andy's has the superior onion rings: giant, fluffy and fresh batter, and hot. the breakfast deals are also cheaper that the latter (around the $7 range), but this place is so tiny and every time i come for a late night breakfast - any time of the week - it's always super packed. service can wane between attentive and dismissive, it's really a hot-cold situation. but like i said - onion rings! as if i needed any more fried food in my life...

also, none of the jukeboxes ever work. EVER.
author: Jenz y.

description: Paid another visit during the SF Silent Film Fest in July and am just getting around to updating my thoughts.  I enjoyed (very much) a turkey breast reuben.  It was on lovely rye bread, grilled with swiss cheese and thousand island dressing and kraut, it was messy and gooey and 100% delicious.  I do not get to the Castro to eat too often, but this was yummers and satisfying.  Alas, I opted to skip the root beer float this time, a mistake, but I wanted to remain awake for the movies.
author: Donna H.

description: Best breakfast! The pancakes melt in your mouth. I don't know what is in them, but they are so good. Great place to go late night because they are open 24 hours. Just watch out for the cook if you have to use the bathroom, because you have to walk through the kitchen and he gets a little pissy....
author: Sarah C.

description: The food is great, the service is a little on the slow side. However the twink waiter is just adorable, so I don't actually mind. The prices are perfectly reasonable and the hours are convenient if you're going to a late  show at the Castro Theater.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: This was my first time visiting Orphan Andy's and my last. I have never been to a place with such disregard for the customer. The Waiter Andrew was had the worst attitude i have ever seen. It is such a shame i heard the food was decent there. But on the real Andrew Kiss My Ass. You should be fired. And i will be talking to  the manager.
author: Lloyd R.

description:
good for owls. i love the chicken vegetable soup... so hearty
the chocolate fugue cake is rich and creamy.
i saw a girl had a tasty sandwich and makes me wanna go there again
author: Florence C.

description: Home fries instead of hash browns. Good food and friendly staff.
author: Scott F.

description: Easy and convenient when you are drunk and starving at 2a.m. The food is fine, but most of the servers that I have had in the past have not been friendly at all. I somehow end up here every few months only to be disappointed by the service once again. The most recent time I was here our waitress was great. However, the time before that my friend and I were not that hungry and wanted to split a meal with a side. We were not drunk just wanted a quick bite to eat. When we placed our order the waiter laughed at us in a condescending manner as if it were a joke that we were sharing a meal and questioned the decision of what we were ordering. It wasn't even busy so we weren't taking up valuable space.
author: Derek H.

description:
In my opinion there are only two reasons to go to Orphan Andy's.  The first is the wait staff, and right up there is their Chicken Fried Steak with the sausage gravy!  Both of these things deserve more than 5 stars. 

Everything else deserves only 1 star.

So I compromised and gave it threes stars.
author: David C.

description: Good late night grub is what this place is best known for.  I cannot begin to tell you how many times I have stumbled into this place toe up from the flo up!   I often wonder why I always manage to sit by those who up & and walk out without paying then end up getting busted for it.  The food isn't free here man!   Ok, so the best things in this place are the Tuna Melt and the Cream Cheese Burgers..   YUMMY!    Its open 24 hours and they take your credit card...  let's see what else, the space is small so seating is very limited and there is counter seating available should you end up by yourself.  The worst time to hit up the place is when its last call, so make sure you stumble over here well in advance before the bar cuts yer sorry ass off!  Just don't go expecting a five star palace because you ain't gettin' that here beyotch.   The place is a dive and cheap, but in my opinion, they offer great late night dining and there is always a free show going on if you catch my drift.
author: Roddster V.

description:
staff:  treats you like family!  everyone is kind, friendly and efficient.

food:  surprising good home style breakfast.
author: Mike O.

description:
Ok, I'll make this quick. I went there once and the fries that came with my order were kind of golden but with a greyish tint. It was like 2am so I was a bit buzzed and very hungry. 

I later realized they looked like that because the fries were cut and left out to dry, giving them that grey starchy look. That's a no-no. Never again.
author: Drew G.

description: A **fabulous** late-night spot. A favorite for those post-2am dining needs.   My favorite: the Steak and Eggs.. the crowd is spectacular.. jump at your next chance to stumble in as the evening winds down!
author: Mr J.

description:
* warning: they have some gayphilia (gay graphical assets) on the walls, so if you're homophobic or from Kansas, you might not want to eat here.

I used to live in Twin peaks, and coming home on Market St after a bar crawl, this place was awesome since it was on the way back to the Palace Flophouse (my old place on Market) and is open 24 hours. And you can order breakfast at 3am, with good quality bacon.

Mmmm. Bacon....
author: service p.

description: Great place for a weekday breakfast if you're in town on vacation.  My server (Matthew) was friendly and, let's face it, rather handsome.  The banana pancakes made my mouth water.
author: Scott S.

description: I eat at alot of diners in SF and Orphan Andys is the best. I love the potato salad. It's just like my mom used to make.
author: Travis V.

description: just had a  bowl of chicken soup and came down with a KILLER migraine and general feeling of SICK.  I think they must have had that soup full of MSG!  BEWARE - ask before you order -
author: J S.

description: disgusting dirty place, I have no idea how come they are allowed to sell food in a place like this, it's gross , there were flies in the cooking area, you have to go through the cooking area to get to the most dirty small toilet, and you have to wash your hands in a dirty sink in the kitchen ...
author: A Z.

description: I used to love this place - fun atmosphere and great food. However on my last visit the food was awful. My friend said his grilled cheese sandwich tasted like Velveeta! My cheeseburger was greasy, with wilted lettuce and the patty was broken into several pieces. I mean how hard is it to grill a burger and not break it? The side of cottage cheese was huge but tasted like it was going bad. I couldn't finish it. Very disappointing meal.
author: Bruce T.

description: Late night dining completes any city and while SF ironically falls short on this feature (even Bourdain called SF a "town"), one can only thank the alcohol gods for Orphan Andy's. Open 24 hours a day and it's not a Denny's = awesome. The food is hearty and your typical diner fair. Nothing fancy and mind blowing could probably only describe the characters that step into this place. Of the past various visits, the sloppy joe, breakfast plates and buffalo wings were all hits so I'm guessing you really can't go wrong with anything else on the menu. And really, when does anything taste bad when you're starving after your $$$ dinner just a few hours prior to your drunken stupor? The place is small though so if you're looking for something as soon as you stumble out that bar door, be prepared to wait.... outside! The guy who works there late night is a fairly adamant about this point and quite a quirky fellow but hey, I'd be annoyed with drunk people as well.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Years ago, the charming Edwardian on Collingwood my friend was renting was sold, and he had a month to find an affordable apartment. Desperate, on the 29th day he rented a studio on an upper floor in the building adjacent to Orphan Andy's.  Unfortunately, his windows overlooked the restaurant's roof, which had a huge exhaust vent spewing grease fumes at him 24/7. As I recall, he lasted three months there, not surprisingly never eating at Andy's. I did once . . . and once is enough.  This is the kind of place that's fabulous when you've got the 4:00am munchies and downright dismal in the daylight when your head is clear.  How has it lasted as long as it has, with far better options just around the corner?  Only if you're absolutely famished between midnight and 6:00am, and even then you've got Safeway a few blocks away. A nuked burrito at home has to be better than anything you'd order here.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I really like this place the more I go.  After going to more SF restaurants, I've realized that the portions are good and the prices are fair.  The waiters are friendly too!
author: Jo M.

description: When i lived in NY, i knew this guy that transplanted the midwest named Steve and he sold insurance. He was a Bears fan, had a moustache, glasses, was about 20 pounds overweight and wore alot of brown suits. He had a wife named Linda and a daughter named Katie. He drove a light blue Nissan Altima, and listened to talk radio. When he did listen to music, he listened to easy 90's and listened to Creed when he wanted to rock. He had a house in the suburbs, which Linda decorated witha  country flair, in alot of magenta and fiorest green, but the garage was reserved as "his" space. In it, he had a couch, a big screen TV and a fridge always stocked with longnecks of Bud and Bud Light. On the other side of the garage was his wife's gold Honda Accord, storage boxes and a fake Xmas tree. Steve and i got pretty close hanging out, so he gave me the code to his garage, to just open and go in, help myself and chill. Id like to say something weird happened to make this story interesting, but it didnt. Basically, its boring and normal, but wiith nice people. Like this diner. Everything is brown, average and normal, and is brought to you by nice people. *sigh* I at least wanted to see an iron maiden in his garage or something.
author: Mick F.

description: I'd have to agree with Leslie.s here.....don't go to a greasy spoon caff if you don't want greasy spoon food!  The older guy who served us was really funny and welcoming and food was hearty and satisfying.  I could have stayed there all day just for the cosy atmosphere.
author: karen M.

description: It was 80s night at The Bar, which means 80s music and 80 cent drinks (I still don't get why a vodka cran was 80 cents and a plain red bull was $3....) put those 2 together and you have one helluva time and it was only a Monday!  So seven of us stumble over to Orphan Andy's for an post-party meal.  Surprisingly, it was easy to get a booth, which only seats 4 comfortably, 6 if you're ambitious--and we were.  Our server was not eager to please, he probably thought drunk people like us wouldn't tip, so why bother.  Well, we tipped him generously even after he threw straws at us and wanted to spend as little time as possible at our table....not very welcoming.  I get it, who wants to serve obnoxious drunkards at 2 am, I'm just letting you know not to expect smiling faces when you come in.  Food is decent, fries suck, french toast is great, chicken fried steak ( I never knew what that meant btw) was a hit among my friends, but I didn't try it.  In general, a suitable place for late night food.
author: Aristocles P.

description: Don't go here.  The employees are rude and I watched a cockroach crawl up the wall in the kitchen. Yuch..
author: Terry B.

description: Thought I'd stop in for breakfast yesterday after going to the bank around the corner.  What a mistake. It was just about the worst breakfast I've ever had. The staff is friendly and i was approached right away but it was a good 15-20 minutes before my combo omelet showed up. Missing inside was the swiss cheese I'd ordered. I let the waiter know, he took it to the back and I heard the microwave start. A few min later it came back. The toast had been microwaved too (after being toasted) and the potatoes tasted, well, like nothing I've ever had before. Greasy, greazzzy, like they'd been on the griddle for HOURS. The omelet was pretty bland except for the grilled GREAZZZZY onions and the eggs, well, they'd been microwaved to get the cheese to melt. I hadn't been in Orphan Andy's for years and believe me I will not be going in again anytime soon. The Cove would have been a better choice.
author: Steven V.

description: I love this place!  With limited seating  capacity just do not try going there at night.  The hamburgers are terrific, the fries nice and golden brown and the shakes are to die for.  And the crowd is fun.  I took my 4 year to OA for the first time and she keeps telling me we need to go back.
author: Rosey R.

description: OPEN 24HOURS!!!!  Love it ...  totally tiny and impossible to get into when there is a crowd.. Especially if you happen to be Female (ahem ahem)...  But, go after you are done clubbing it up at the Cafe or anywhere for that matter.  Diner food.. Gots ta love it when it is good.  Duh.. I know..  Grilled Cheese! CHECK!!  Meatloaf Sandwich! CHECK!  French Fries! Check!  what more could you ask for from a Diner!  I know I certainly couldn't.  Seriously though, 24 hours.. That means you could get a meatloaf sandwich or a hamburger at 3 in the morning if you so choose.  I personally do not think I could stomach something like that at that time of night but hey, I will always order some toast or a grilled cheese just so you can feel better about grubbing so late.  Besides, sometimes one just needs food at that hour so they can drive home....  not a bad reason to stop in and sit for a minute or two or maybe 30 just to be "safe".
author: Kylie L.

description: This was the worst service I've ever had in a restaurant ever.  There is a waiter there who works the late night shift named Andrew, and he was so aggressive and rude that my friends and I decided to leave.  I've never done that before.
author: Alex M.

description: Normally a great late night spot, thanks to a certain waiter by the name of ANDREW, I will not be coming back here for a while.  Extremely rude and clearly on his period, he shooed a group of us just waiting to hear our wait time, outside.  We were clearly unworthy of his space and the music selections that were apparently his even though my friends put their money in the juke box.  He also seemed aggressive with the busboys who were actually working hard and pleasant.  TWO THUMBS DOWN!
author: Sara H.

description: How can it be that after years of perfecting my foodie arrogance that this restaurant ends up being one of my favorites in the city? Maybe it's the hand drawn picture of the naked guy riding a dolphin? Maybe it's the kick'in tunes on the jukebox? Maybe it's the "seen it all" crowd? It's not a mystery I care to solve anytime soon, i just know this place feels comfortable and always has perfect timing.
author: Mark R.

description: my king didn't like the eggs from his breakfast
author: Lady O.

description: Cute decor, patient and friendly service, average food, for a reasonable price. Menus are conveniently placed at the table and although space is limited, it feels nice and cozy once you're seated. The spacing is a lot more intimate than most diners. I would rather go here than Denny's any day/night unless you're with a bigger crowd.
author: Katie N.

description: a diner with gray-haired waitors in cut-off jean short-shorts? this is like someone from west palm beach serving you eggs benedict on rollerblades in miami. and yes, it is greasy spoon deliciousness at it's best, and totally full of character(s).
author: julia r.

description: I was here at about 3pm on a Saturday and it was predictably quiet. I lived in the neighborhood for 8 years and never came here because an old roommate said it was terrible and that review just stuck in my craw - plus with Sparky's so close why go anywhere else. My mom puts together a poetry journal called Diner and she asked me for some pics so I've been doing a diner tour of the city. I sat at the counter at Andy's and ordered a side of frys and a coke and just snapped away. The frys were of the skin attached variety and fried to a pleasant golden hue. The plate was large but so is my appetite for frys and I got all the way through it. Obviously I can't speak to what Andy's, or the Gay Diner, as I like to call it might be like at 3am or during the breakfast rush but I had a very pleasant experience here and would definitely come back. I recommend one of the two tables near the front window so you can people watch and see the old streetcars as they make there way to Market St.
author: Colin S.

description: Ahhh Orphan Andy's, many a drunk night I have stumbled into your arms and you've held me till the bad man stopped or at least till my head stopped spinning.  Orphan Andy's is one of my favorite places to go after my friends and I have been putting back a few beers and really don't have the will power or body strength to get our asses anywhere else.  In times of need we turn to you Andy, your open 24 hours, your food is pretty good, and I'm always guaranteed to run into some Sassy queen who always swears I look like Macy Gray or Jill Scott (not my favorite part of the evening but I'm drunk enough to take it as a compliment and i know there pretty much just referring to the obscene amount of curly hairs on my head). Orphan Andy's I think your even good enough to eat sober and that my friends says alot because I usually don't do anything sober.  So on a yum scale I'd give it a : High or not, drunk or not, I might actually stop by. If your not busy that is.
author: Marie B.

description: the waitstaff here is really nice, they aren't that veggie friendly but they are open 24 hrs a day. is a diner, it serves diner food that about it.
author: Jared Z.
